Group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-based contrasts are reported (multiple whole-brain contrasts, cluster thresholds, MNI coordinates reported in tables and figures), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Results are reported for the healthy adult sample and are generalizable to the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (social working memory) in healthy adults (n=25, mean age 21.6, within 17–65). The task is explicitly social (ranking friends on trait dimensions) and includes an objective perspective-taking behavioral measure. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (parametric modulation, conjunctions, and contrasts) with tables of clusters/coordinates and thresholding details, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and results are reported for the healthy/control sample. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=63; age range ~20–36) using a social incentive delay task probing social reward processing (faces) versus monetary reward. The paper reports group-level, univariate task-evoked whole-brain results (tables of coordinates and whole-brain/ROI-corrected contrasts such as social>monetary and reward>neutral; FWE-corrected maps are reported and coordinates/tables provided). Results for the healthy sample are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. Analyses include whole-brain activations (and ROI SVC), figures and tables with coordinates. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or clinical-only contrasts. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study reports an original task-based fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=41, mean age ~22) using a social-affective mimicry task examining affiliation-related processes. Group-level, whole-brain, univariate contrasts are reported (e.g. Incongruent > Congruent and masked contrasts) with cluster-level correction and tables of peak coordinates (Tables 2–4), enabling voxelwise inference generalizable to healthy adults. The design and reported within-group task activations meet the meta-analysis constructs (affiliation/social cognition). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not resting-state or connectivity-only; healthy adult subgroup reported). Therefore the paper satisfies all inclusion criteria for the fMRI meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social attribution (why/how task) in healthy adults (N=19, ages 21–46). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (conjunctions and interaction contrasts), with cluster-forming thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, tables of coordinates (Table 2) and whole-brain statistical maps/figures. The social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others, theory of mind) are central to the task. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, healthy adult sample within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical dfMRI study in healthy adults (19 pairs; 38 individuals; ages 18–33) using task fMRI of face-to-face eye contact (a social interaction). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain GLM results (task A and B), paired t-tests to derive exogenous/endogenous maps, cluster tables with MNI coordinates and atlas labels, and thresholding (Z>2.3, p<0.05). Results are presented as whole-brain activation maps and probabilistic atlas labels generalizable to a healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses task fMRI in healthy adult dyads during a social (joint attention) task and the sample ages and healthy-group reporting meet inclusion, the paper does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. The analyses are data-driven ICA component extraction and cross-brain coupling/permutation tests (multivariate and connectivity-oriented); results are reported as ICA spatial components and coupling indices rather than traditional voxelwise GLM activation maps or coordinate tables of whole-brain task effects. This falls under the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only ICA/connectivity analyses without an accompanying whole-brain task activation map. Therefore it must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18, ages 18–44) using a social prediction task probing perception/understanding of others (desire- vs rule-based behavior). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses with cluster- and voxel-level results and tables of coordinates (Tables 2–3) and figures, and describes activation maps generalizable to the healthy sample. It is not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state study, nor a non-empirical paper. Age range, sample, and reported whole-brain task activation maps satisfy all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are met.

Meets all inclusion criteria: empirical fMRI study of social processing (deception, theory-of-mind/social cognition) in healthy adults (N=34, ages 21–32). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., simple and sophisticated deception vs. truth; parametric analyses) with posterior probability maps and coordinate tables from a Bayesian second-level analysis, clearly coming from the healthy participant group. Not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of emotional crowds and interaction dynamics). Sample: 16 healthy adult participants (ages 19–27), reported separately. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (random-effects ANOVAs) with tables of cluster peaks and coordinates (Tables 1–3) and whole-brain maps, corrected for multiple comparisons. The task is an event-related dot-detection task while viewing dynamic crowd videos (social content). The study is empirical and reports original whole-brain activation results for a healthy adult group, meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (perceiving person interactions), addressing social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=12, ages 21–31), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., incongruent > congruent; whole-brain results shown in tables/figures and described in text), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses also include ROI/MVPA but whole-brain, task-evoked results for the healthy group are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social communication in healthy adults (N=37, ages 20–39). The task explicitly probes social-related processing (feeling addressed; body orientation and co-speech gesture). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (main effects and interaction contrasts) with cluster-corrected voxelwise results and tables of peak coordinates (e.g., IC>NG, ego>allo, interaction maps), clearly from the healthy participant sample. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only approaches. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This source is a conference abstract with insufficient methodological detail: participant sample (number, ages, healthy adults) is not provided, and the text does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (voxelwise results or coordinates) for a healthy adult group. The report focuses on methods (dual-head coil, dual logic) and derived networks but does not present clearly identified whole-brain healthy-group activation maps. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence and adequate sample reporting; exclude.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI examining social-related processing (social language/mentalizing during a social-communication paradigm); the sample is healthy adults (n=19, mean age 20.55 within 17–65); and the paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (parametric whole-brain maps and cluster-corrected results are described and shown—see Figures 5 and 6 and Tables 4 and 6). It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts. Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (final N = 13, mean age 24.85). The task probes social processing (initiating and responding to joint attention) using an interactive gaze-contingent virtual-reality paradigm. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., RJA - RJAc; IJA - IJAc), corrected for multiple comparisons (FDR) and lists peak coordinates and statistical maps/tables for whole-brain effects. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and is empirical with original fMRI data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication in healthy adults (54 right-handed males, age 18–27). The task explicitly probes social communication and mutual understanding. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (e.g., parametric/logarithmic modulation of BOLD over time, whole-brain search, cluster-level corrected results) identifying regions such as right superior temporal gyrus, with statistical inference generalized to the healthy participant sample. Although additional connectivity/coherence analyses are included, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and contrasts for the healthy group are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, non-healthy-only sample) are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (dynamic formation of social ties during a repeated public-good game), using a social-related task (other-regarding/affiliation and perception of others). Sample: healthy adult participants (25 scanned, mean age ~22.6), results reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task-evoked analyses (parametric modulators, contrasts) with MNI coordinates and cluster-wise FWE-corrected thresholds (tables/figures described). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and is original empirical work in healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults (N=18, age 19–28) investigating social communication (perception of text messages attributed to a friend vs a computer). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., friend minus computer) with cluster results and coordinates (Table 2) and SPM maps, satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. The task probes social-related processing (mentalizing/social closeness) rather than only ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social sharing/affiliation) in healthy adults (female participants age 20–33). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain analyses (exploratory whole-brain corrected activations in left DLPFC and bilateral precuneus; main effects of emotion reported whole-brain), not only ROI results. Contrasts (shared > unshared; emotional > neutral) are clearly described for the healthy participant group and generalizable within the reported sample. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (fMRI social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain univariate results reported). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=50, ages 18–29) that uses a social-perception task (labeling briefly presented emotional facial expressions — perception/understanding of others). The authors report group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (HA>NE, AN>NE, FE>NE) and voxelwise regression analyses with coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction; results are presented in tables and figures for the healthy sample. Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Sample, task, and whole-brain reporting meet all inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of biological motion/social cues) in healthy adults (n=26, ages 18–39). The authors report group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses of biological-motion selectivity and its relationship with social-network measures, including a cluster in right pSTS that survives correction for multiple comparisons, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results from the healthy adult sample are reported separately and are generalizable to the healthy adult population. The study is empirical, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and does not violate any exclusion criteria. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study used fMRI in healthy adults on a social-related task (voice–face person recognition) and reports group-level voxelwise modeling. However, all significant effects are reported only with ROI-based inference and ROI/FWE-corrected coordinates; the authors explicitly note no significant results at P<0.05 FWE for the whole brain without the covariate. There is no unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) healthy-group task activation map presented as a generalizable main effect—only ROI- and PPI-based results. This fails the inclusion requirement for a reported whole-brain group-level univariate task map, so the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (20 right-handed male volunteers, age 20–28) using a social-related task (passive viewing of traffic-awareness campaign videos designed to induce empathy). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (CV > NV contrast), with significant clusters reported at p<0.05 FWE-corrected and cluster peaks used as ROIs; these whole-brain voxelwise effects are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study reports an fMRI neuroimaging experiment examining interpersonal synchrony and social-affiliative processing in which participants served as referents. The abstract explicitly states a neuroimaging (fMRI) study and describes activations in brain areas implicated in social cognition, embodied cognition, self-other processing, and action observation (e.g., dmPFC, IPL, premotor areas), indicating task-evoked brain activation results. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (total N=100 across studies, with a neuroimaging cohort reported), meeting the healthy adult sample requirement. The paper appears to report group-level whole-brain activation correlates (not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses). Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria of fMRI during a social task in healthy adults with whole-brain task-evoked results.

This is an original task-based fMRI study of social cognition (implicit/explicit theory-of-mind/false-belief processing) in healthy adult participants (initial N=20; MRI analyses N=16; mean age 22.7). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM contrasts (e.g., false-belief > false-photo/map) with cluster thresholds and Talairach coordinates, SPMs, and whole-brain analyses for both the explicit ToM localizer and the implicit false-belief task. Results are univariate, voxelwise, and clearly described for the healthy/control group. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults with whole-brain group-level activation maps) and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

Study reports an fMRI task of social person evaluation (impression formation) in healthy adult participants (N=20 male, ages 19–31). The paper includes whole-brain, group-level voxelwise results: an exploratory whole-brain analysis is described (threshold p<.005 uncorrected, cluster extent), with tabulated MNI coordinates and figures reporting main effects and interactions across status conditions. It is not limited to ROI-only analyses and presents univariate task-evoked activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level results) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=16; ages 18–25) using a social competitive task (matching-pennies) after brief social interactions with human/robot/computer agents. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM analyses (one-sample t-tests on parametric modulators), voxelwise thresholding (p < .001) and cluster-level FWE correction (p < .05), with peak coordinates presented in tables. Results are not ROI-only, nor resting-state/ connectivity-only, and healthy-group task effects are clearly described. All inclusion criteria are met (task-based fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group results), so the study should be included in the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=32 analyzed; mean age 23.3) that used a social interaction task (an fMRI-adapted Taylor Aggression Paradigm) probing processing of angry vs. neutral facial expressions. The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain task contrasts (angry > neutral) with cluster-wise FWE correction and tables/figures of activation coordinates for decision and outcome phases. Results include whole-brain clusters and ROI analyses, not ROI-only or connectivity-only findings. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

While the study is an fMRI investigation of a social task (Ultimatum Game) in healthy adults (n=28, mean age ~25) and reports group-level GLM contrasts, the second-level analyses were explicitly conducted within a restricted mask composed of 16 bilateral ROIs (wfu_pickatlas). This means the reported voxelwise results are ROI-masked rather than whole-brain. The review requires at least one univariate, whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task activation map generalizable to healthy adults. Because the paper reports only ROI-masked/region-restricted whole-brain results (no unmasked whole-brain voxelwise maps), it does not meet the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=19, ages 18–35) investigating social cognition (triadic interactions, self- and other-referential processing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., triad > iron, conjunctions, triad > (self & other), self > (triad & other), other > (triad & self)) with coordinates and significance thresholds (p<0.05, whole-brain FWE-corrected) and tables/figures of activations. Although PPI connectivity analyses are also presented, the study includes clear whole-brain activation maps/results for the healthy control group and meets the age and participant criteria. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, or non-healthy-only samples) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults: 10 healthy right-handed male participants (age 22–32) were scanned while viewing dyadic point-light displays depicting typical vs. atypical social interactions. The authors report group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., (atypical-upright+atypical-inverted)-(typical-upright+typical-inverted)) with cluster-corrected statistical maps and tables of peak coordinates. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately and are generalizable within the adult range. The paper also includes connectivity analyses, but it does not rely solely on ROI or resting-state/seed-only methods. All inclusion criteria are met and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in a healthy adult sample (n=20 males, mean age 24.6) using a social-related task (viewing first-person video clips of neutral, social-positive, and reactive-aggressive interactions). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise group-level task contrasts and conjunctions (FDR-corrected; tables of peak coordinates and glass-brain figures are provided), not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. The task maps clearly index social-processing constructs (perception/understanding of self/others and social communication). All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social influence/emotion alignment in healthy adults (n=20 scanner participants, mean age ~23.95, right-handed) and directly addresses social processing (social communication/appraisal/conformity). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (random-effects, clusterwise FWE correction) for anticipation and picture-viewing phases, with tables/figures of voxelwise results (e.g., insula, amygdala, ventral striatum). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult group results reported). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social feedback processing (self/other trait evaluations) in healthy adult German and Chinese participants. The task is clearly social (perception/understanding of self and others; affiliation/feedback). fMRI was acquired and analyzed with whole-brain, group-level univariate GLM contrasts and parametric modulators; results report whole-brain voxelwise activations (FWE-corrected clusters and coordinate tables) and group-level contrasts (e.g., self>other, parametric effects), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample comprises healthy adults and results for the healthy groups are reported separately. The paper reports task-evoked, univariate, whole-brain activation maps and tables, not solely ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=21, mean age 23), investigating social cognition (self-referential processing and intergroup competition). The design used task-evoked, event-related fMRI and an independent self>other localizer. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses (Tables 1–2 and supplementary whole-brain maps/coordinates) in addition to ROI work, using corrected thresholds. Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control sample and include voxelwise activation coordinates generalizable to healthy adults. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI of social processes in healthy adults with group-level whole-brain task activation results).

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of self vs other). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=18; ages 19–29). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts and peak coordinates, including whole-brain FWE-corrected results and conjunction analyses (in addition to ROI/SVC), clearly from the healthy-control group. Analyses are generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to a special subgroup. It is not ROI-only, nor connectivity or resting-state only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (Cyberball exclusion and a modified Dictator Game probing punishment/forgiveness — constructs: social exclusion, affiliation, perspective-taking, theory-of-mind). Sample: healthy adults (N=26 after exclusions; mean age 20.7), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Excluders > Includers; Excluders equality > Includers equality) with tables of peak coordinates and multiple clusters, and notes FDR-corrected results — satisfying whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results, and healthy-group effects are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (attributing awareness to others) conducted in healthy adults (n=50; ages 18–49). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate activation contrasts (H trials − E trials) with cluster-corrected statistical maps, Talairach coordinates, figures (Figs. 3–4), and a table of peak/centroid coordinates, all clearly coming from the healthy/control group. The task is a social-related paradigm (perception/understanding of others). Although the paper also includes a subsequent TMS experiment, the fMRI component meets the inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria are violated (results are not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and not limited to a special-age sample). Therefore the study should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognitive processing (causal attributions to self/other/situation) in healthy adults (N=20, ages 18–41). The paper reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses and lists coordinate tables and conjunction/contrast results with FWE-corrected clusters (whole-brain and small-volume corrected ROIs). The methods and results clearly present univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample (contrasts vs baseline and between-locus contrasts). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (right-handed volunteers aged 18–27). It investigates social-related processing (bystander effect, perception/understanding of others and helping behavior). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (parametric GLM and contrasts) with tables of Talairach coordinates and statistical maps (Tables 1–3, figures), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for the healthy sample are reported directly and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or non-empirical methods, and participant ages fall within 17–65. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy participants, the functional results are reported using predefined ROI analyses (beta extractions and ROI-based GLMs) rather than reporting any group-level, unmasked whole-brain voxelwise task-activation maps or coordinates for healthy adults. The review’s inclusion criteria require at least one group-level whole-brain univariate task map from the healthy adult group. Therefore the study must be excluded.

Meets inclusion criteria: (1) Uses fMRI during a social-related task — social distance trials required participants to evaluate photos/names of friends vs acquaintances, addressing perception/understanding of others. (2) Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=15; ages 20–28), within the 17–65 range. (3) Reports whole-brain univariate task analyses: a GLM and voxelwise paired t tests (sooner vs later; closer vs farther; more vs less familiar) and a conjunction analysis were performed and described at the group level. Although these univariate results yielded no FDR-corrected significant voxels (null results), the study nonetheless reports whole-brain, group-level task-evoked statistical analyses applicable to healthy adults. Not excluded by any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, empirical fMRI data present). Therefore include.

The study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (undergraduates, mean age 18.9 within 17–65). The fMRI faces-versus-houses task is a social-perception-related contrast (face processing / perception of others). Whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses were conducted using SPM8, with significant clusters reported (Table 2) and thresholding described (p = 0.05 FWE corrected for group activations; suprathreshold voxel counts in bilateral fusiform gyrus also reported using p < 0.001 uncorrected). Results are presented as voxelwise activations and coordinates, not solely ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (reciprocal imitation/online social interaction) in healthy adult participants (23 right-handed females, age 18–30). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked GLM contrasts (imitating, being imitated, observation vs rest) with familywise-error-corrected results and tables of coordinates, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirement. Although it also includes PPI connectivity analyses, the presence of univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy group means no exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (familiar/partner faces → affiliation/attachment/social cognition). It includes a separate healthy control group (n=13, mean age 64.5) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts for the control group (e.g., partner > unfamiliar face) with voxelwise coordinates and FWE-corrected statistics. The task and reported control-group whole-brain activation maps directly match the review objective. Confidence is 0.80 because participant ages are described as “older healthy volunteers” with mean 64.5 (SD 5.7); while the group clearly comprises healthy adults, exact individual age ranges are not provided, so there is some uncertainty about whether all controls fall within the 17–65 bounds.

Although this is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (age range within 17–65) and reports whole-brain analyses, the reported group-level whole-brain statistical maps are contrasts between subgroups (proself vs prosocial) and interaction effects. The paper does not present an unmasked, within-healthy-group task activation map (e.g., task > baseline or main task effect across all healthy participants) that is clearly identified and generalizable to the healthy adult group. Per the exclusion criterion disallowing studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task effect, this study must be excluded.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition (empathy, Theory of Mind, self–other differentiation) in a healthy adult sample (n=15, males aged 21–40). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses (main effects and contrasts; cluster-extent and voxelwise thresholds; tables/figures of activations/coordinates), not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply (healthy adult group reported separately, within age range, whole-brain task activation maps provided).

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication/empathy in healthy adults (N=27, mean age 34). The task involves social communication (facial expressions, prosody, speech content) relevant to Social Communication and Perception/Understanding of Others. The authors report group-level, random-effects whole-brain GLM contrasts (e.g., E > N and channel-specific contrasts), present voxelwise activations (figures and peak MNI coordinates), and perform conjunction and ROI analyses. Although they also report DCM (effective connectivity) and FIR ROI analyses, the paper clearly includes univariate, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy/control group that are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state, healthy adult sample within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and should be included in the review.

This is an fMRI study of explicit social judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) on vocal stimuli in healthy adults (N=44, ages 21–60). It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (GLM; voxelwise maps thresholded and cluster-level FWE-corrected) with MNI coordinates and tables of activations. The task targets social-related processing and the healthy control group results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants fall within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This fMRI study investigates live verbal social communication (interpersonal speech/listening) in healthy adult participants (22 right‑handed women, mean age 27.2). It reports group-level, voxelwise univariate analyses (first- and second-level voxel-wise t-tests) for talking, listening and imagining, with whole-brain results presented (figures and supplementary tables, cluster-thresholding and Monte‑Carlo correction described). The task is a clearly social communication paradigm and results are generalizable to healthy adults rather than a narrowly defined clinical subgroup. The paper does not rely solely on ROIs, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses and includes original empirical fMRI data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole‑brain task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

Although the paper investigates social/moral sentiments in healthy adults, it is a structural VBM study (grey matter volume) and does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked fMRI activation maps for the healthy/control group. The manuscript references and uses previously collected SSC-BOLD responses from a subgroup (N=29) for secondary correlational analyses, but it does not present an independent, unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task activation map in this publication. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI results and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adults (N=32, ages ~24) that manipulated social context (collaboration, individual, competition) during a task and reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate activation maps (SPM results with clusterwise FWE correction and tables/figures of activations). The task probes social-related processes (collaboration/competition, social position, pro-social bias), satisfying the construct domain. Results for the healthy participant group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper includes whole-brain maps and coordinate tables rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (Dynamic Social Gesture) in healthy adults. The sample comprises 20 healthy young adults (mean age 21.4; range 16.9–25.7) and results are reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., social > nonsocial; actor-orientation; face-visibility) with cluster inference (TFCE) and permutation testing and provides figures/tables of activations and coordinates. Although one participant is marginally under 17 (16.9), the cohort is otherwise adult and group-level healthy adult results are clearly reported and generalizable. Thus the study meets the review’s criteria for task relevance, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked maps.

The paper reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (empathic judgments/ emotional egocentricity) in healthy adult participants (several independent samples of right-handed female undergraduates). It includes group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (fMRI Experiment 1 reported whole-brain results/cluster coordinates and thresholds; fMRI Experiment 2 used independent ROI/SVC but also performed whole-brain analyses). Peak coordinates and statistical maps are reported; results are generalizable to a healthy adult group. The study therefore meets the inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, and group-level whole-brain task activation).

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants performing a social-evaluation task (approachability judgments of faces), which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others.’ The abstract and text describe task-evoked contrasts and report activations in multiple brain regions (e.g., left amygdala, medial/middle/inferior frontal gyri) tied to specific task conditions, indicating group-level univariate whole-brain voxelwise results rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. There is no indication the sample was clinical or outside the 17–65 age range, and results for the healthy group are reported directly. Therefore the paper meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task activation maps in healthy adults and is eligible for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=19 analyzed; ages 19–41) using a social attribute-framing task that probes self- and reflected-perspective social cognition (perception/understanding of self/others). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., task>control, positive>negative frame, negative>positive frame, frame-inconsistent>frame-consistent) with thresholding and peak coordinates described, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. No clinical or special groups confound the healthy-group reporting. The study is empirical and provides original task-evoked whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not trigger any exclusion criteria.

This paper is a narrative review/overview (title and abstract explicitly state it is a review) and does not present original empirical methods, participant details, or reported whole-brain, group-level univariate fMRI statistical maps or coordinate tables for a healthy adult sample. Although the abstract mentions authors’ recent fMRI findings, the provided full text is descriptive and lacks primary methods, sample characteristics, or univariate voxelwise results that would meet the inclusion criteria. Therefore it fails the requirement for original task-based fMRI data with whole-brain healthy-group results and meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical/review papers without original fMRI data in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI task study using traffic-awareness video stimuli that probe socio-cognitive processes (mentalizing/empathy, perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adult drivers (ages reported within 19–30 and 20–? groups; means 23–24 years), fitting the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (GLM, random-effects), within-group CV vs NV contrasts and whole-brain results illustrated in figures and detailed in tables of peak coordinates (Tables 2–3, Figures 1–2), which satisfy the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain maps and coordinates. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or out-of-range ages) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related—third-party punishment and moral judgment engaging mentalizing and perception/understanding of others. (2) Sample: 26 healthy adult participants (mean age 26, within 17–65). (3) Whole-brain, group-level, voxelwise analyses are reported (random-effects GLM; whole-brain FDR q<0.05) with Talairach coordinates for activations (R TPJ, R anterior insula). (4) Results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated: the study is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports univariate whole-brain task activations for healthy adults. Therefore include.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 19–28). It investigates social-related processes (eye-gaze detection, self-propelling animacy, and implicit mental-state inference). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., E–O, S–X) with voxel-wise statistics, cluster correction, and tables/figures of coordinates and activations (i.e., not ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only). Results for healthy controls are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social impression formation (perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (N=19; mean age 19.1, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., form impression > remember order localizer and main-task 2×2 ANOVA) with cluster correction and tables of coordinates (Tables 1–2). Results are not limited to ROI-only analyses; whole-brain maps/coordinates are presented and clearly reported for the healthy participant group. No clinical/special groups confound the healthy sample. The task and contrasts are social in content and meet the meta-analysis inclusion criteria (whole-brain task-evoked activations in healthy adults).

This is an fMRI study of social perception using a task (naturalness ratings of dyadic nonverbal interactions) in healthy adult participants (final N=21, ages 23–33). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., contingent vs mirrored, rigid vs smooth) with cluster-corrected statistical maps and coordinate tables (Tables 1–3) clearly derived from the healthy/control group. The methods describe standard whole-brain preprocessing and random-effects second-level analyses. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind/emotion/pain judgments). Sample: 46 healthy adult participants (female, 18–31), meeting the age and healthy-sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., B > Ph, E > Ph, Pa > Ph) with cluster-level correction and tables/figures of activations (MNI coordinates), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for a meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (recognition of vitality forms / perception and understanding of others) in healthy adults (N=19, ages 21–29). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (contrasts such as how vs what; what/how vs baseline) with coordinates and PFWE-corrected results presented in tables and figures. Although ROI analyses are also performed, whole-brain results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants in the 17–65 range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-processing (message propagation/mentalizing, social communication). Participants are healthy adults (interns N=19, mean age 20.55; producers N=79), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate task analyses (buzz, intention, salesperson effects) with voxelwise thresholds and MNI coordinates (whole-brain results reported and thresholded; Table/Figures described). The design is task-evoked (encoding show descriptions) rather than resting-state or connectivity-only, and results are not limited to ROIs or only between-group contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (reward for self, friend, antagonist) in healthy adults (N=31; ages 18–26). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task analyses (ANOVAs and contrasts) with tables of MNI coordinates and statistical thresholds; results include whole-brain effects and corrected clusters (FDR/FWE and small-volume corrections) rather than ROI-only findings. The task clearly probes social constructs (affiliation/other-referential processing) and the reported maps are generalizable to a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria. The study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (ages 18–45; final N=41) while they viewed images of human suffering and applied compassion or reappraisal strategies—this is clearly social-related processing (empathy/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (suffering vs. neutral) and a whole-brain Group × Redistribution Rank interaction with results whole-brain corrected (right IPC identified at p < .01 corrected); conjunction and follow-up whole-brain analyses (DLPFC) are also reported. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, the article also provides univariate whole-brain activation maps and coordinates for the healthy control sample. Results for the healthy group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. Not ROI-only; not resting-state–only. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (imitation/observation of communicative vs non-communicative gestures) in healthy adults (N=20, mean age 24.6). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., IMI>CT, S>NS, interaction effects) with cluster-level correction (Monte-Carlo) and tables listing MNI coordinates (Tables 3–4) and figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task directly probes social-related processing (communicative intention, mentalizing, mirror-neuron systems). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adult results). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception and evaluation of social information in different laughter types, including an explicit laughter-type categorization task), conducted in healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 26). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (second-level random-effects contrasts such as CSL>TIC and CAT>COU) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and presents activation results in figures/tables. Although the study also includes connectivity (PPI) analyses, it clearly provides univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample rather than only ROI or connectivity-only results. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria for the review.

This fMRI study examines social communication (communicative vs private intentions) in 23 healthy right‑handed adult participants (mean age 24), well within the 17–65 range. It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., CInt > PInt) with peak coordinates and tables, interaction effects, and whole-brain maps, satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. While PPI connectivity analyses are also reported, they are supplemental to and do not replace the univariate whole-brain results. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, empirical data in healthy adults). Therefore the study qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (speed-dating paradigm) in healthy adult participants (scanned N=38; ages 19–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts and tables of significant voxelwise activations with MNI coordinates (e.g., Tables 1–4; contrasts such as Yes > No, Match > Unrequited, prediction-error correlations). Results are reported for the healthy control/participant group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROIs, connectivity-only, or non-healthy samples. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing about groups vs. individuals) in healthy adults (Experiment 1: n=25, ages 19–27; Experiment 2: n=14, ages 18–23), which falls within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., group mental > group physical; member mental > member physical; individual mental > individual physical; belief > photo) with coordinates, cluster sizes, and corrected statistical thresholds (Tables 2, 4, 5 and figures). Analyses are random-effects and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and does not report only between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

While the study uses task-based fMRI of social processing in a healthy adult sample (n=15) and reports ROI-based MVPA and a whole-brain searchlight MVPA, it does NOT provide a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group. The authors state that univariate SPM group analyses for the key interaction yielded no significant voxels surviving whole-brain or small-volume correction. The reported whole-brain results are multivariate (searchlight-correlation MVPA) rather than conventional univariate activation maps. Therefore the paper fails the ’whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and meets the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only ROI/multivariate analyses without an unmasked, group-level univariate healthy-group task activation map.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI study of social-related processing (comparative judgments of others’ attractiveness/height — perception/understanding of others). Sample: 25 healthy adult women (mean age 23.46), within 17–65. Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (whole-brain random-effects analyses, voxelwise thresholds, cluster FWE correction) with tables of coordinates and conjunctions — not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state results. Healthy-group effects are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria violated.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=24, ages 18–27). Tasks include Why-How questions about people’s actions (social inference/understanding of others) and Categories-Exemplars, eliciting mentalizing and action networks. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts (e.g., How>Why, Exemplars>Categories) with cluster-corrected thresholds and tables of coordinates (Table 2), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes healthy adults). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=17, mean age 23.5) investigating interpersonal conflict — a social-related task (perception/understanding of others, social decision-making). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Conflict > No Conflict, interaction HUMAN>COMPUTER) with tables of coordinates and statistical maps, clearly from the healthy group. Analyses are not ROI-only, nor solely connectivity or resting-state, and results are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an original fMRI study of social/person-related processing (famous faces, personally familiar faces, social closeness judgments) in healthy adults (final N=15 female; mean age 22.3). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level, random-effects univariate analyses and voxelwise contrasts (FDR- and cluster-corrected thresholds) with Talairach coordinates and maps for contrasts of interest (e.g., famous vs. unfamiliar, friends vs. unknown). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and results for the healthy adult sample are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n≈36, ages ~21) using a social-related task (perception of others’ pain/empathy). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (painful vs non-painful) with FDR-corrected whole-brain results and tables of MNI coordinates; it also presents whole-brain post-priming contrasts. Healthy-control group results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not violate any exclusion criteria (no resting-state/seed-only analyses, age within 17–65, whole-brain task activation maps provided). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (trustworthiness judgments of faces) in healthy adults (initial N=16; imaging analyses N=14; ages ~22), which falls within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, voxel-wise task-evoked analyses (2×2 repeated-measures ANOVA) with cluster correction and provides peak coordinates/tables for main effects and interactions (Tables 2–4). Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition contrasting interactive vs. observational conditions in a sample of healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 25). The task is explicitly social (ostensive cues, joint attention, object-directed gestures). Analyses used a two-level GLM with group-level RFX whole-brain ANOVA and one-sample t-tests; exploratory whole-brain results (e.g., visual cortex) are reported alongside ROI small-volume-corrected results, and peak voxel MNI coordinates are provided for task contrasts. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. Thus the study meets inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI in healthy adults with group-level voxelwise statistical results (whole-brain analyses and reported coordinates).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21, mean age 24) investigating action observation/execution and mirror-system responses, which pertains to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ (a social-related construct). The paper reports group-level univariate fMRI analyses including both ROI analyses and a whole-brain analysis (threshold p<0.001 uncorrected) with coordinates and SPMs described for main effects of adaptation, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy group. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study does not fall under any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not patient-only, and is empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of visual perspective-taking/theory-of-mind in healthy adults (n=16, mean age 22.4), using a task probing self vs. other perspective selection — a clearly social-related construct (Perception and Understanding of Others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Inconsistent Other > Consistent Other, Consistent Self > Consistent Other) with voxelwise thresholds, cluster-level FWE correction, and tables of activation coordinates. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults (ages within 17–65). The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusions.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (action understanding; why/how/what/how tasks) in healthy adults (initial N=19, one excluded, final sample within 17–65). It reports group-level, random-effects univariate contrasts (conjunctions, F contrasts, load-by-goal interactions) and provides voxelwise cluster coordinates for task-evoked activations in mirror neuron and mentalizing systems; the authors note whole-brain results and supplemental whole-brain methods/results are available. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses, and results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria (social fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and group-level whole-brain task-evoked results). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (social reasoning/theory-of-mind) in healthy adults. Sample: 45 neurologically normal undergraduates (ages 19–23), satisfying the 17–65 criterion. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (task > rest and domain contrasts), random-effects analyses, conjunctions, and peak coordinates (Appendix A), with whole-brain statistical maps/figures described in the text. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses; resting-state data are reported separately and do not replace the task-based whole-brain effects. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (perspective taking and empathy for others’ pain) in healthy adult participants (n=18; ages 21–31). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (Self vs Other, View-Pain vs View-No-Pain, conjunctions, good vs bad performers) with voxelwise results and cluster-/peak-level FWE-corrected statistics and tables of coordinates. The healthy group results are presented and generalized to the healthy adult population. The study is empirical, not ROI- or connectivity-only, and meets the age and sample requirements. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related task-based fMRI study probing affiliative/attachment-related social processing in healthy adults (final N=27, mean age ~27, within 17–65). The study reports group-level, random-effects, univariate whole-brain analyses (contrasts: affiliative vs nonaffiliative, affiliative vs neutral, valence contrasts) with FWE-corrected voxelwise results and peak coordinates, and figures showing whole-brain statistical maps. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity or between-group contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social perception in healthy adults (N=19; ages 21–34). The experiment used task-based fMRI with naturalistic movie stimuli targeting multiple social constructs (faces, bodies, biological motion, intentional action, emotion, social interaction, pain, speech). Group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM) are reported (first- and second-level analyses, contrasts, t-maps) with voxelwise correction (p<0.05 FDR) and coordinates/figures provided. The healthy adult sample is within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper also reports additional connectivity analyses but crucially includes whole-brain task-evoked maps rather than ROI-only or resting-state-only results. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition that examines neural processing of social interaction goals (cooperative vs. affective). Sample: 27 healthy adult participants (ages ~24–26), within the 17–65 range, with results reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts and statistical maps (e.g., cooperative vs. landscape, affective vs. landscape; direct comparisons), using random-effects analyses and FWE-corrected thresholds; conjunction and interaction maps are also described. Although ROI analyses are included, whole-brain voxelwise results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (affiliation/romantic love vs. power) in healthy adults (final sample: 17 male students, mean age 23.6). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (affiliation > control and power > control) using mixed-effects analyses, and provides activation clusters with MNI coordinates (Table 1 and figures). Analyses are univariate task-evoked maps (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only) clearly reported for the healthy sample. All required inclusion criteria are met; no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults: 39 recruited, 36 analyzed healthy adult subjects. The task (‘Other’ task) requires subjects to predict another person's choices (simulation of others’ decisions), which falls under 'Perception and Understanding of Others' / social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate fMRI results (Tables 1 and 2; whole-brain corrected p<0.05 clusters and voxel coordinates are provided) for task-evoked contrasts (sRPE, sAPE, reward probability, RPE). Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable within the healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not resting-state/ connectivity-only; includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=94, females aged 18–35) investigating compassion/empathy using the Socio-affective Video Task (a social-affective task). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate analyses (e.g., HE vs LE video contrasts, parametric modulations) with results thresholded at P<0.05 FWE and tables/coordinates provided; independent ROIs were also used but whole-brain effects are reported. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are clearly reported. The study is empirical and not excluded by any criterion (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, includes within-group healthy task activations). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants using task-based movie viewing of emotional/social stimuli. The authors report group-level, voxelwise intersubject correlation (ISC) analyses identifying synchronized activity across participants in multiple brain networks and relate ISC time series to valence and arousal; these are whole-brain, task-evoked voxelwise results generalizable to healthy adults. The study addresses social-related processing (emotional contagion, understanding others) and does not rely solely on ROI-only, seed-based connectivity, or resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of empathy/ social processing (self, friend, stranger threat) in healthy adults (final N=22, mean age 23.6 within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (threat vs safe) and group-level conjunction and higher-level whole-brain analyses (z=2.3, cluster p=0.05), with coordinates, figures and supplementary whole-brain results; these maps are clearly reported for the healthy/control sample. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and does not report only between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of affective speech comprehension (social communication/perception of others) in healthy adults (N=51, ages 18–53). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (EMO vs GRAM) with voxelwise statistical maps and corrected results (FWE), plus coordinates and figures. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and results for the healthy control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (impression formation/updating), conducted in healthy adult participants (N=24; ages 18–45). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Faces+Behaviors vs Faces Alone; interaction and L2>F3 contrasts), with thresholding, cluster-size correction, figures and supplementary tables listing activations/coordinates. Although fROI analyses are included, whole-brain voxelwise results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and participants are within the 17–65 age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-referential processing (self vs other) using the VV-SORP-T, directly addressing perception/understanding of self and others. Sample comprises healthy adult participants (women aged 18–52) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task-evoked analyses (SPM8 GLM; group-level contrasts such as S-N and S-P vs fixation and S-N vs O-N, S-P vs O-P) with reported cluster tables/figures and ROI/SVC follow-ups; thus it provides generalizable healthy-group whole-brain activation maps. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of empathic (social) decision-making in healthy adult participants (N=32 males; mean age 22.8), fitting the target constructs (empathy/perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (cluster-level whole-brain correction P<0.05 for most contrasts; tables of activations are provided), along with conjunction and GLM contrasts and coordinates. Although some vmPFC results use small-volume correction, multiple whole-brain contrasts and tables (Tables 1–5) are reported, so it is not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Participants are within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=16, mean age 20) that uses a social working memory task (mentalizing/perspective-taking). The manuscript reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise univariate analyses (parametric load regressors) with coordinates and thresholding details and surface-rendered maps; results are described for delay and probe periods and include tables of peak coordinates and cluster thresholds. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 17–43) using a social-related task (in-group vs. out-group action perception; constructs: perception/understanding of others, affiliation). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., single-video > fixation; own-team > other-team; paired-judgment > press) with cluster-level FWE correction for the whole-brain search volume and voxelwise thresholds (P<0.001), and provides coordinates and statistical maps in the text/tables. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants within 17–65, healthy sample). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of emotional prosody comprehension (social communication/perception of others’ emotions), which falls within social-related processing. Sample: healthy adult participants (n=19 males, age range 18–51) within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (emotional vs neutral; complex vs simple emotions), thresholded and corrected for multiple comparisons (cluster extent correction across the whole brain) and presented in text and figures. Analyses are univariate task activation contrasts rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=13; mean age 28.2) using a biological-motion task that assesses perception/understanding of others’ actions (social-related processing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate contrasts (canonical vs scrambled biological motion) with corrected significance and tabulated MNI coordinates and figures, and uses random-effects analysis — satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Although it also includes connectivity/DCM analyses, it provides univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. Participants are within the required age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply, so the study meets all inclusion criteria.

While this paper uses fMRI during a social task (the ultimatum game) in healthy adult participants (ages 23–28) and reports whole-brain multivariate classification results (SVM/RVM weight maps identifying discriminating volumes), it does not present a group-level univariate, voxelwise task-evoked statistical map (e.g., GLM main-effect or within-group contrast) as required. The reported whole-brain results derive from multivariate classification/weight maps and ROI analyses rather than conventional univariate group contrasts. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level univariate whole-brain activation map for healthy adults, this study does not meet all criteria and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=20; mean age ~25, within 17–65). It uses an explicit social-related task (Cyberball) probing social exclusion/affiliation and reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (e.g., social exclusion > fair play; same- vs other-gender exclusion) with cluster-corrected voxelwise results, tables of coordinates, and figures. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain results are clearly provided and generalizable to a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of task-evoked social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social competition invoking Theory of Mind (social interaction) in healthy adults. Sample: 14 right-handed healthy volunteers (mean age 35.9), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, random-effects, voxelwise univariate task contrasts (e.g., I> C; H>I+C>M>I+C; interaction [H(I>C)]>[M(I>C)]) with thresholding (p<0.001 uncorrected, cluster size reported) and tabulated peak coordinates (Tables 2–4). The task is social-related (human vs. machine competition; ToM-like processes). No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or out-of-range sample limitations are present. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults assessing social processing.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception and integration of facial and vocal emotions — social communication) conducted in healthy adults (N=24, age 18–34). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (RFX-GLM) with voxelwise contrasts (e.g., AV > A, CAV > ICAV), thresholding and FDR correction, conjunction analyses, and tables/figures of activation clusters and coordinates. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical. Results for the healthy control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=19, ages 19–28). The task involves social-related processing (stereotype/social-category judgments and person knowledge) and compares social vs non-social semantic judgments. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects contrasts ‘social’>‘non-social’ and ‘non-social’>‘social’) with corrected cluster thresholds and tables/figures of peak coordinates and activations, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants are within the 17–65 age range, and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and not a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (n=20, mean age 18.7). Participants completed a task comparing close (romantic partner) and non-close (roommate) others; analyses used second-level random-effects GLMs and report group-level voxelwise contrasts with peak coordinates (multiple contrasts, e.g., Target × Breadth, Valence, Close vs Non-Close). Results are reported as voxelwise activation peaks and clusters (with correction applied within a priori ROIs) and are clearly described for the healthy control sample. The sample falls within the 17–65 range and the paper provides group-level task-evoked activation maps/coordinates generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., patient-only sample, resting-state/only connectivity, or ROI-only reporting without group contrasts) prevent inclusion.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (eye contact and mimicry) in healthy adults (N=20; mean age 23, all right-handed, no neurological history) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM contrasts (e.g., Congruent > Catch, Incongruent > Catch, Direct > Averted, interaction contrasts) with thresholding and cluster-level FWE correction; results are reported in tables and figures. Although DCM connectivity was also performed, the paper clearly provides task-evoked whole-brain activation maps for the healthy control group. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI during observation of virtual social interactions (a social cognition task). It reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (social interaction vs. no-interaction) with activation maps and t-value maps based on data from 15 participants, indicating whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy group. Participants are described as recruited with informed consent and standard adult screening; results are presented for the (healthy) participant group rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. These elements satisfy the review’s inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult group, and whole-brain group-level activation maps). Confidence is moderate-high because participant ages are not explicitly listed in the excerpt, but other details strongly indicate a healthy adult sample.

This fMRI study (N=25, Mage=20.2) tests prosocial/family-assistance decisions—clearly social-related processing (affiliation/mentalizing). Participants are healthy young adults within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain/univariate contrasts (e.g., Costly-Donation vs Noncostly-Reward) with tables of peak coordinates and t-scores (Tables 1–3) and whole-brain/ROI-corrected inference procedures. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample (no clinical groups). Although ROIs were used for some corrections, whole-brain regression and contrast results are presented and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (20 young adults) viewing dynamic social interaction vignettes (positive and negative), addressing social processing. The abstract and reported results describe group-level, univariate whole-brain activation (right > left activation in amygdaloid complex, inferior frontal gyrus, fusiform gyrus, temporal gyri; p<0.0001), which indicates voxelwise, within-group task effects rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Participants are healthy adults within the eligible age range. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only samples, or non-empirical paper) appear to apply. Note: full PDF is behind a paywall so coordinate tables/figures could not be inspected, but the abstract explicitly reports whole-brain hemispheric activation results. Given available information, the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (representation of social interaction/social context vs. solitary and self-generation) in healthy adults (N=24, ages 18–28). Group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts are reported (e.g., (rSS+rSO)-(rNS+rNO), (rSS+rNS)-(rSO+rNO)) with tables of coordinates and cluster-level correction (p<0.05) and figures showing activation in mPFC, MCC, etc. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state only, and reports healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.
