This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=31, ages 18–35) using a social-perception task (viewing faces with/without facial disfigurement while performing a gender judgement), which addresses ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (pre- vs post-surgery faces) analyzed with SnPM and corrected for multiple comparisons; activations and deactivations are explicitly reported (cluster-level FWE-corrected, tables/figures described). The sample falls within 17–65, and results for the healthy group are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only samples) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social interaction perception in healthy adults (N=21; ages 18–35). The study used task-based BOLD fMRI with GLM-based analyses, subject-specific and group-constrained ROI localization (interaction>scrambled, bodies>objects, faces>objects, mentalizing>pain), and performed whole-brain procedures including group-level whole-brain analyses for localizers and whole-brain searchlight analyses. Results report group-level classification and searchlight outcomes localized to bilateral LOTC/pSTS and discuss group-level contrasts used to define ROIs. The sample fits the 17–65 healthy adult range, and the paper provides whole-brain task-evoked analyses (localizer contrasts and searchlight). The study is neither resting-state nor connectivity-only and reports within-group effects generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task uses fMRI to measure processing of dynamic facial expressions (social communication/perception of others), sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=51; mean age 22.5, right-handed; within 17–65), and the paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate task contrasts (dynamic expression > dynamic mosaic) with family-wise-error-corrected voxelwise results and tables of coordinates. Not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This study meets all inclusion criteria. It reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (N=78, ages 18–40) including multiple social-related tasks (false belief/ToM, intentional triangles, vocalizations, trustworthiness, eyes intention, face judgments). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise activation maps and contrasts (RFX analyses with voxelwise p<0.05 FWE-corrected), supplementary tables of peaks, and figures of activation maps—i.e., univariate whole-brain task-evoked results for a healthy adult sample. It is empirical fMRI work (not ROI-only or resting-state only) and results are reported for the healthy group, so it should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (social exclusion via the Cyberball task) in a healthy adult sample (N=71 female adults, mean age ~21.7). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, task-evoked whole-brain analyses at the second level (flexible factorial, random-effects), with reported coordinates and clusters (right AI, rTPJ, subACC) and correction for multiple comparisons (FWE SVC); results are univariate activation contrasts derived from healthy participants. The methods and results clearly describe whole-brain voxelwise statistical maps (reported in text/tables/figures), not ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 19–36; N=111 total; 38 participants contributed to the fMRI analyses after exclusions) that uses an explicit task requiring animacy judgments of a moving dot — a social-related construct (perception/understanding of others/animacy). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (conjunctions and random-effects ANOVAs) with voxelwise results thresholded and corrected (e.g. FWE-corrected clusters reported; coordinates and tables referenced in main/supplementary materials), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only, and task-evoked activations for the healthy/control group are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses fMRI with a social task (Cyberball) and includes a healthy adult control group (N=17, ages within range), the paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map or within-group contrast clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Reported results focus on between-group contrasts (BPD>HC, NSSI>HC) and conjunctions; no standalone HC whole-brain activation map or coordinates for the healthy-group main effect (e.g., inclusion vs passive watching in HC) are provided in the text/tables. Per the review’s inclusion criteria, studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=49, ages 18–33) that used a social-related Face Processing Task (fearful vs neutral faces) engaging socioemotional processing. The paper reports group-level, task-evoked univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses (F > N and N > F contrasts) with family-wise error correction using TFCE and permutation testing, and provides coordinates, figures, and whole-brain exploratory results applicable to the healthy sample. Although ROI and functional connectivity analyses are also reported, the manuscript clearly includes unmasked whole-brain task activation maps and coordinates generalizable to healthy adults. Sample age and group meet inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is a task fMRI study of social communication (co-speech gestures) in healthy adults. Sample: 20 healthy native German adults (ages 22–35) meeting the age-range criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., low_ID > high_ID; speech > gestures+speech; gestures+speech > speech) with tables of activation peaks, cluster extents, and MNI coordinates and describes cluster-level correction — satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed connectivity only, and reports healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy for pain/pleasure toward human vs. robot), using a task-based design in healthy adults (N=26, ages 18–27). The paper reports group-level whole-brain random-effects analyses (main effects and interactions), cluster-corrected results, and provides whole-brain group contrast maps (NeuroVault) and coordinate tables. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps for the healthy sample are clearly reported, satisfying inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, clinical-only sample, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study of live social interaction (human–human vs human–robot conversation) in a healthy adult sample (N=21, mean age 25.8, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise contrasts (main effects and HHI versus HRI) with cluster-level FDR correction and provides neuroimaging results generalizable to healthy adults. The task probes social-cognitive constructs (mentalizing, social motivation, social communication). It does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and presents whole-brain task activation maps/tables. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria (healthy adult group reported separately; whole-brain univariate results presented).

Although this study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants (mean ages in range) and examines social-relevant face perception and recognition, it does not clearly report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group in the full text excerpt provided. The analyses are primarily multivariate (MVPA, representational similarity) and ROI-based, and while an independent localizer (n=83) was used to define ROIs, the paper does not present or describe an unmasked, voxelwise group activation map or whole-brain contrast for the main task or localizer in the provided content. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one clearly reported group-level whole-brain univariate task map, this study does not meet all inclusion criteria and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (real-time mutual eye contact/social communication) in healthy adults (n≈30; mean age 21.7–21.8, all within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., LIVE > REPLAY) analyzed with SPM12 and cluster-level FWE correction, with coordinates and cluster information provided. Although additional connectivity and interbrain analyses are reported, the manuscript includes univariate voxelwise activation maps/results generalizable to a healthy adult population. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state–only, not a methods/review paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI targeting dynamic facial expression processing, a clearly social/cognitive domain (perception of others). The methods describe a stringent localizer contrast (dynamic facial expressions > static neutral faces + moving dots) and report that the target region (pSTS) was successfully identified across subjects, implying a group-level, voxelwise task contrast generalizable to healthy participants. The paper is empirical, reports real-time fMRI neurofeedback experiments, and is focused on healthy adult participants (no exclusive clinical-only sample). Therefore it satisfies: (1) social-related task fMRI, (2) healthy adult sample, and (3) group-level whole-brain task activation results. Confidence moderated because the provided excerpt lacks explicit participant age ranges and full methods, but the abstract and RFX/GLM terminology indicate appropriate whole-brain reporting.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of theory of mind in healthy younger and older adults, the full-text abstract indicates the primary reported results focus on resting-state/intrinsic functional connectivity within a task-defined network rather than reporting group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group. The paper emphasizes intrinsic connectivity and mediation analyses of resting-state connections; it does not clearly report voxelwise whole-brain task activation maps (or coordinate tables) for a healthy adult group that are generalizable to the healthy population. Additionally, participant ages are described as younger and older adults but specific age ranges are not provided in the abstract, raising potential uncertainty about whether all healthy participants fall within 17–65. Because the inclusion criteria require a clearly reported healthy-group whole-brain task activation map, and that criterion is not clearly met, the study should be excluded.

Although the study used fMRI with a healthy, age-matched control group, it does not report a clear, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map that is explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. The reported whole-brain results are primarily: (a) a main effect of Task computed across both groups, (b) between-group contrasts (Autism vs Control), and (c) connectivity-based analyses (seed-to-voxel, region-by-region, and resting-state comparisons). Inclusion criterion 3 requires at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group that is generalizable to healthy adults. Because the paper focuses on connectivity and group contrasts without providing an unmasked, whole-brain control-group activation map, it fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

Although this study uses fMRI during a social-related task (interpersonal pleasant touch) and reports results for a healthy control group (matched non-using adults), the provided full-text content (abstract and metadata) does not explicitly confirm that group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group are reported. The abstract describes striatal activation differences and between-group effects, but does not state whether whole-brain voxelwise results or coordinate tables/figures for the healthy group are presented. Because the inclusion criteria require clear reporting of at least one unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect, and that information is not available in the supplied text, I must exclude the paper for insufficient evidence of whole-brain results.

This study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=44; mean age 22.4) during an explicitly social interactive task (cooperation/competition in a two-player Pattern Game). It reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate GLM results (random-effects FLAME analyses, non-parametric permutation correction) with clusters, coordinates, and thresholded t-maps described in the text and figures. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, pediatric/clinical-only, or non-empirical limitations apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult males (ages 18–35) using a social provocation task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) that probes social cognition/response to others. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., high>low provocation during feedback and decision phases) with MNI coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction, clearly from the healthy/control sample. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or resting-state/connectivity-only methods. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults with whole-brain univariate results).

This is an fMRI study of social perception (trustworthiness appraisal) using a task probing perception/understanding of others. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=17, ages 18–45) reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (parametric regressions and contrasts across conditions) with group-level results described in the text and supplementary tables/figures (e.g., whole-brain analyses of fearfulness and trustworthiness, task contrasts, and reported coordinates/cluster results). Results for the healthy/control group are described (ROI and group comparisons) and findings are generalizable to healthy adults within the sampled age range. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (ages 18–22) during a social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma), meeting the social-processing construct. Group consists of healthy participants and results are reported separately for these groups. The paper includes group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses (CC and CD contrasts; whole-brain GLM with cluster correction, reported Z thresholds and clusters; coordinates/tables provided), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample is within the 17–65 range and healthy. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social decision-making (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) performed in healthy adult participants (N=20 males, ages 21–37). The paper reports univariate, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (one-sample t tests and flexible factorial second-level analyses) with FWE cluster-corrected results and tables/figures of activations for task phases and treatment effects. Results for the healthy sample are reported at the group level and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not limited to connectivity/resting-state, and includes original empirical fMRI data. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (imaging sample N=29, 1 excluded; remaining participants aged 18–22). The task involved mental-state judgments (social perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: a searchlight representational similarity analysis (whole-brain maps corrected via permutation TFCE with peak coordinates reported in medial PFC) and a voxelwise univariate repetition-suppression analysis (one-sample t tests across participants, whole-brain TFCE-corrected results with peak coordinates in precuneus). Results are not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (face-based trustworthiness judgments with feedback). It includes a healthy younger adult group (N=24; ages 20–33) within the required 17–65 range and reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task analyses (ANOVA and contrasts) with cluster coordinates and statistics (see Table 1 and whole-brain results described in the text and supplement). The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, and provides univariate task-evoked whole-brain activation maps (congruence effects, age effects, age × feedback interaction) that are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age outside range without applicable subgroup, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24; mean age 26) that examined social-relevant processing (integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions — social communication/perception of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., bimodal > unimodal fearful stimuli; congruency contrasts) with FWE-corrected results and coordinates, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirement. Healthy-group results are reported and generalizable to adults 17–65. Although ROI and DCM analyses are included, they do not replace the whole-brain maps; whole-brain task activations are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (emotional face recognition of own vs. unfamiliar child — social communication/perception of others). Participants include adult mothers (healthy control group CON explicitly defined as mothers without any lifetime mental disorder), meeting the healthy adult sample requirement. The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., own>unknown and other contrasts) with FWE-corrected whole-brain results and within-group effects; CON group whole-brain effects are reported (medial frontal gyrus for own>unknown). Analyses are univariate voxelwise task activations (not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, only between-group contrasts, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=55, males, mean age 24.9) using a social-related task (processing of erotic and fearful social scenes and emotional faces). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task activation results (e.g., erotic>neutral, fearful>neutral, erotic>fearful) with whole-brain FWE-corrected findings and coordinate/figure reporting; ROI analyses are supplementary but whole-brain univariate maps are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of task-evoked social processing in healthy adults.

This study includes a social-related task (social cognition: social interaction vs. random movement) performed in a healthy adult sample drawn from the HCP (unrelated subjects aged 22–35) and UCLA dataset; healthy-group results are reported separately. The paper reports voxel-wise GLM activation analyses and group-level one-sample t-tests with corrected statistics (FDR) and displays whole-brain task activation maps (figures and supplementary materials), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain, univariate task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. Although the paper also focuses on connectivity (PPI/BSC), it explicitly reports whole-brain activation results for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, empirical data in healthy adults).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (recall of self- and other-related relationship episodes) conducted in a healthy adult sample (n=35, mean age 33.85). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (self-relevant>control, other>control, etc.) with cluster-level FDR-corrected results and tables listing coordinates. Analyses are whole-brain (not ROI-only), not limited to resting-state or connectivity-only methods, and the healthy-group results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply.

Meets all inclusion criteria. This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=19, mean age 25.9) using a social-related task (perception/discrimination of affective vocalisations — social communication/perception of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (species contrast human > chimpanzee > macaque) with voxelwise results and MNI coordinates reported in Table 2 and images (p < .001), clearly identified for the healthy adult group. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are reported and generalizable to the healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore include.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult humans (n=23; ages 24–34) during a social-related task (perception of emotional facial expressions). The authors performed group-level random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (reported voxel- and cluster-level corrected maps, stereotactic coordinates, and figures/tables of activations) for contrasts such as dynamic faces versus scrambled and emotion×configuration interactions. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately and are generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup). The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes whole-brain activation maps and coordinates for the healthy adult participants, meeting all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using a naturalistic, socially engaging movie clip (Toy Story) to probe social-cognitive processing. The sample includes a healthy adult group (reported separately) and results include group-level, whole-brain voxelwise inter-subject correlation (inter-SC) maps and between-group contrasts, with peak coordinates and cluster-level inference reported. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or resting/seed-based connectivity; whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for the adult (healthy) group are clearly presented and generalizable. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (task-evoked social processing, healthy adult group, and whole-brain group-level results). Exclusion criteria are not violated.

Participants are 16– to 17-year-old adolescents (sample described as 80 neurotypical 16- to 17-y-old males). The review requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65 or a separately reported adult subgroup; this study does not report a separate adult (≥17) healthy group. Additionally, the paper’s primary reported results focus on task-based functional connectivity rather than reporting a clear group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for a healthy adult group. Because the age criterion is not met and no adult whole-brain univariate activation is clearly reported for the required population, the study must be excluded.

The study reports task-based fMRI of social evaluative processing (social inclusion/exclusion), matching the review’s social-related constructs. Sample consists of healthy adolescents/young adults (N=56 analyzed; age range 17–20), which falls within the 17–65 inclusion range and is a healthy-group sample (exclusion of current Axis I disorders and other health exclusions). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (positive>neutral, negative>neutral, conjunctions) using voxelwise statistics with familywise error correction (P<0.05 FWE), and these effects are described for the healthy group rather than only ROI or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI with group-level whole-brain contrasts relevant to social processing (peer endorsement, reward, cognitive-control networks), the sample consists exclusively of adolescents (age range 13–18) with analyses reported for that adolescent group as a whole. The meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adult participants (age 17–65) reported separately or results generalizable to healthy adults. This paper does not report a separate adult healthy-group analysis nor focus on participants within an adult age subgroup; therefore it fails the sample-age inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

Although the paper includes a healthy control group, it does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy adults. The analyses are task-state functional connectivity (ROI cross-correlation and seed-based voxel-level connectivity with Fisher z-transforms and conjunction analyses) rather than standard whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts. Per the review exclusion criteria, studies reporting only seed-based/ROI connectivity without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map must be excluded. (Note: participants are older adults/aMCI vs controls, reinforcing that the primary exclusion is lack of whole-brain univariate task maps.)

Sample is adolescent rather than adults: n=22 youths mean age 17.0, range 15.47–18.72, so participants under 17 are included and no separate healthy adult (17–65) subgroup is reported. Although the study used task fMRI of social/parent stimuli and reports group-level whole-brain contrasts, it does not provide a healthy adult group within the review’s required age range. Therefore it fails the sample inclusion criterion.

This paper reports a task-based fMRI study of social/attachment processing (maternal neural response to infant cry), matching the review’s constructs (affiliation/attachment). Participants are adult mothers (mean age 24.1, within 17–65); at scan none met criteria for current major depression and results are reported for the healthy sample (analyses controlling for depressive symptoms and excluding medicated participants yielded similar findings). Critically, the study reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task activation results (own cry > control and own > other contrasts) with cluster-wise thresholding and coordinates in tables/figures. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor limited to between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task activation maps in healthy adults and should be included.

This is an fMRI task study of social evaluation/impression formation (social-meaningful and social-irrelevant vs non-social) in healthy adults. It includes a young healthy adult group (ages 20–29), which falls within the required 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, random-effects, voxelwise univariate analyses (contrasts, conjunctions) with corrected cluster thresholds and peak coordinates, not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Group-level activation maps and coordinate tables are described for the healthy groups and contrasts (e.g., conjunction of young and older, age-group contrasts), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the review.

Participants are adolescents across three developmental phases (study examines adolescent development of reciprocity); no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported or analyzed separately. Therefore the sample does not meet the review’s adult age-range inclusion criterion. Even though the study used task-based fMRI of social behavior, the absence of a qualifying healthy adult group means it does not provide whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (inhibiting prejudice/perception of stigmatized others). Participants include healthy young and older adult groups (young adults within the 17–65 range). The abstract reports voxelwise activity differences in regions (medial and lateral PFC) tied to task contrasts (viewing stigmatized vs. control faces) and group comparisons, indicating whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses rather than ROI-only or resting-state methods. Results are reported for healthy adult groups and are generalizable to the healthy population rather than limited to a clinical subgroup. Therefore the paper meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

Although this study used task-based fMRI and reports whole-brain, voxelwise results (MPFC activation and MPFC–striatal PPI) during social-evaluative contexts, the participant sample spans ages 8.0–22.9 and is not an adult-only sample. The paper does not present a separate group-level whole-brain task activation map derived solely from a healthy adult subgroup (17–65) nor an unmasked, generalizable adult-group main effect—results are reported as age-modulated effects across the mixed-age sample (child–adolescent–young adult) and focus on nonlinear age predictors. Because the meta-analysis requires whole-brain task activation maps that are clearly identified as coming from a healthy adult group and generalizable to the adult population, this study does not meet the inclusion criterion of reporting adult-group whole-brain activation separately. Therefore it should be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social regulation (hand-holding by friend/stranger) in healthy adults (n=22, mean age ~23), addressing social affiliation/attachment. The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate analyses (threat vs. safe contrasts) using FSL with cluster-wise thresholding and lists ROIs/coordinates in Table 1; these results are presented for the healthy participant group. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results are not limited to a clinical subgroup. The study is not ROI-only, nor resting-state or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

Meets inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related — decisions made under advice from an ‘adult expert’ (social influence / perception and understanding of others). (2) Sample includes a healthy adult group (n=24, ages 18–45) reported separately alongside adolescent groups. (3) Whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked results are reported (voxel coordinates and cluster results for regions such as vmPFC, DLPFC, TPJ, caudate; whole-brain thresholding and cluster correction described). (4) Results for the healthy adult group are separable and generalizable to healthy adults. Notably, the study also includes adolescents, but adult results are reported and interpretable independently. Therefore it qualifies for inclusion as an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (allocentric social hierarchy and social alliance judgments) in healthy adults. Sample: 22 healthy right-handed male adults (mean age 24.2), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., social hierarchy vs. baselines; social alliance vs. number-equal) with results presented as SPM maps and tables of Talairach coordinates, corrected at p<0.05 FWE. Analyses are univariate task activations (not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state), and healthy-group effects are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (impression formation/violations of social expectations; mentalizing/individuation), using healthy adult participants (18 included in final analyses; ages 19–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (incongruent > congruent) submitted to random-effects second-level analyses, with a table of whole-brain coordinates (Table 1) and FDR-corrected results. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain univariate results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only; not connectivity-only; participants are within age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of affective/social touch (CT-targeted gentle brushing), a social-related task (affiliation/attachment; social perception). Sample: 22 healthy right-handed adults aged 19–35 (within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate random-effects GLM results (arm>baseline, palm>baseline, arm>palm) with voxelwise thresholds, FDR/cluster correction, and tables of peak coordinates and figures. A PPI connectivity analysis is included but the paper clearly presents univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social perception (impression formation; perception and understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (N=60 males, mean age 23.8). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses (exploratory whole-brain regressions with voxel-wise thresholds and reported significant clusters, e.g., VMPFC cluster), not only ROI results. It therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked group results). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study (block design) investigating cross-modal face and voice integration, a social-related perceptual process (social communication / perception of others). Sample: 20 participants (MeSH lists Adult and Young Adult), satisfying healthy adult group requirement. The abstract reports group-level, voxelwise univariate analyses using multiple statistical criteria (super-additive, max, mean) that identified brain regions (e.g., left hippocampus, occipital and temporal cortices), indicating whole-brain task-evoked results generalizable to the healthy group. Although the study also includes PPI, it reports whole-brain activation loci rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy, perspective-taking, self–other distinction) in healthy adults (n=23, ages 19–34). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Pain > No Pain: Similar, Pain > No Pain: Dissimilar, No Pain: Dissimilar > Similar) with voxelwise results, tables/figures, and cluster coordinates, not limited to ROIs. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, they are supplemental to whole-brain activation results. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is empirical original research with task-based fMRI data. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/only connectivity, not restricted-age or non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21 heterosexual male undergraduates, mean age ~21). The task probes social cognition (passive viewing of sexualized vs. clothed male/female targets targeting mentalizing/agency). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (4×21 ANOVA, deviant-cell contrasts) with voxelwise threshold p < .001 and cluster correction (AlphaSim), and presents whole-brain activation results in tables/figures (including correlations between hostile sexism and voxelwise activity). It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or clinical groups. Therefore it satisfies the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

The study reports fMRI (event-related) during a social-related task (perception of others' emotional facial expressions/empathy) in 14 healthy adult volunteers (mean age 29±6, within 17–65). Group-level whole-brain univariate analysis was performed using Statistical Parametric Mapping and identified dorsal medial frontal cortex activation tied to perception of emotions — satisfying the requirement for an unmasked, voxelwise healthy-group task effect generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and does not report only between-group contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this fMRI study uses a social incentive delay task and includes a healthy adult control group (N=24, ages 19–36), it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. Results are presented mainly as between-group contrasts (BPD vs HC), ROI (amygdala) analyses, and exploratory whole-brain effects that refer to patient > control contrasts; the authors explicitly state there were no suprathreshold whole-brain effects in several models and no significant voxels for the HC group in the regression analysis. Therefore the paper fails the requirement to provide an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked statistical map and must be excluded.

The study uses fMRI with a social task (Cyberball) in adults and reports whole-brain group-level contrasts (EX–IN, SUP–EX). However, the sample includes 9 participants with diagnosed social anxiety disorder, and all reported whole-brain analyses are conducted on the combined sample rather than on a healthy-only subgroup. The inclusion criteria require that studies including clinical groups must report healthy-group whole-brain results separately. Because the paper does not provide unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation maps specifically for the healthy/control subgroup, it fails the ‘Sample’ and ‘Whole-brain evidence from healthy group’ inclusion criteria and must be excluded.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants during a social interaction (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma), it does not report any group-level whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task activation maps for the healthy/control group. The paper focuses on ROI-based univariate analyses and task-based functional connectivity (gPPI) results, and explicitly states prior voxel-wise analyses of the same dataset exist elsewhere, but such whole-brain maps or coordinate tables are not presented in this manuscript. Per inclusion criteria, a whole-brain task activation map (or equivalent coordinate table) from the healthy group is required; because this is absent, the study must be excluded.

The study uses task-based whole-brain BOLD fMRI during a socio-emotional preferential task (SePT) that probes social appraisal of faces (a social-related construct). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; mean age ~41.5) and reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain statistical results (FWE-corrected clusters) from task contrasts; the text explicitly states that both HC and SZ recruited medial prefrontal/ACC during SePT and presents whole-brain task effects and coordinates (Figures/Tables and Supplementary materials). Thus it meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample with reported results, and (3) whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps/generalizable healthy-group effects. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and healthy-group task activation is reported).

This is an fMRI task study using the Animated Triangles Task (a validated social/mentalizing paradigm). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (N=17; mean age ~23.6) and the paper reports within-group task activations for controls (intentional > random movement) using whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analysis (FSL/FLAME group-level analysis with cluster correction). Whole-brain statistical maps/activations for the control group are described and shown (figures and supplementary material), and results for healthy adults are reported separately despite inclusion of a clinical group. The study therefore meets the inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy adult group, and whole-brain univariate healthy-group task effects).

This is a task-based fMRI study directly probing perception/understanding of others’ emotions (regret), a social-related construct. Participants are healthy adults (two samples of N=24 each; ages within 19–31 and 19–30), meeting the age and sample requirements. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (contrasts IP minus IF and OP minus OF, parametric modulators for regret/disappointment), conjunction analyses, and voxelwise statistical maps/activation foci with thresholds and coordinates (SPM5). Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Healthy-group whole-brain task effects are explicitly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social-related task (self- vs other-touch) relevant to social processing (perception/understanding of self and others). It includes a healthy adult control group (age range mean ~23–24, within 17–65) with results reported separately. The paper reports univariate whole-brain task-evoked effects for the control group (e.g., whole-brain contrasts and figures for other-touch and self-touch in neurotypical controls, FWE-corrected whole-brain results), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence generalizable to healthy adults. Although a clinical ADHD group is also included, healthy-group maps and contrasts are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age out of range) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation maps for the control group (face processing and affect labeling contrasts), the sample comprises boys aged 10–18 (controls mean age ~12). The review requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65 or a separately reported healthy adult subgroup. This paper does not provide a distinct healthy adult sample or report results limited to adults within 17–65. Therefore it fails the sample-age inclusion criterion despite meeting the fMRI whole-brain reporting requirement. No other exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=20, ages 21–47) employing a social-related task (explicit simulation of others’ actions/feelings during viewing of boxing clips). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked BOLD analyses (GLM contrasts such as simulate > watch and simulate-loser > simulate-winner) with statistical thresholding (FDR cluster-level), figures of activation maps, and ROI analyses; results are generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, resting-state-only, or limited to clinical groups. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This article is a methodological tutorial/review of intersubject correlation analysis rather than an original empirical fMRI study. The full text does not report new data from a healthy adult sample nor present group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for a healthy/control group. It primarily describes methods, examples from prior work, and practical considerations. Per the meta-analysis exclusion criteria, non-empirical/methods-only papers without original fMRI data in healthy adults should be excluded.

While this study uses task fMRI with a social-related face-processing paradigm and includes a healthy adult control group (n=19), it does not provide a clearly identified, unmasked within-group whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group generalizable to healthy adults. The reported whole-brain maps and coordinates appear to be for the combined sample (TLE + controls) or derive from between-group contrasts (HC > RTLE, HC > LTLE). Because the review requires an explicit healthy-group whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map, this paper fails the 'whole-brain evidence' inclusion criterion despite meeting other criteria (task type, healthy adult sample). Therefore it should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of maternal attachment and distress signals including a healthy adult control group, but the reported neuroimaging results are presented using a priori ROI-based analyses (left extended amygdala, NAc, dmPFC) with small-volume corrections and seed-based gPPI connectivity. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map or voxelwise healthy-group contrast generalizable to healthy adults; main reported effects are ROI-limited and between-group contrasts. Therefore it fails the review’s requirement for at least one whole-brain, univariate task-evoked healthy-group result and meets the exclusion criterion for ROI-only/ROI-corrected reporting.

This is an empirical fMRI study using the HCP social cognition (Animated Triangles) task, directly probing social perception/understanding. It includes a healthy adult control group (N=25) reported separately from the patient group. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation results for the healthy controls (e.g., V5 and pSTS activations with MNI coordinates), thresholded at p<0.05 FWE whole-brain corrected, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the study also includes a clinical group, healthy-group results are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of voice-identity/speaker recognition — a social-communication / perception-of-others task — with healthy adult control groups (n=16 and n=16; ages ~29–34). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts for controls (e.g., vocal>non-vocal and speaker>speech) with statistical maps and coordinate tables. Results for healthy/control participants are presented separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI on social processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level univariate maps reported). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy to dynamic multimodal social stimuli). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=24; mean age ~35, within 17–65) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task analyses (mixed-effects GLM, F- and T-contrasts), thresholded cluster-corrected maps and stereotaxic coordinate tables (Tables and figures) and explicitly describes within-group contrasts for each participant group, including controls. The healthy-group task effects are therefore available as whole-brain activation maps/coordinates and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or missing healthy whole-brain maps) are violated. Accordingly the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of theory-of-mind (false-belief) reasoning—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). The paper includes healthy adult reference groups: a large MIT sample (n=462; age range 18–69) and a Caltech sample (n=18; age range 21–46). The manuscript reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for the Belief > Photo contrast for the MIT reference group (voxelwise, FWE-corrected) and for the Caltech group (cluster-level corrected), and these healthy-group maps are clearly described and generalizable. The study therefore meets the fMRI, social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain evidence inclusion criteria. It does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy-group whole-brain maps are provided).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (evaluation of political beliefs involving self–other processing, social decision-making, and perspective-taking). Sample: healthy adult participants (fMRI N=26; ages 22–45), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, task-evoked whole-brain analyses (second-level random-effects; statistical maps thresholded and peak coordinates reported; Table of coordinates and Talairach values provided). Analyses are univariate task activations (parametric modulation) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Although the study includes healthy adult controls and uses task-based fMRI during a social perception task (biological motion), it does not report a group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation map for the healthy/control group that is generalizable to the healthy adult population. The imaging results are based primarily on individual-subject localizers and ROI-based (STSp, MT) event-related analyses; whole-brain analyses described were conducted in patients (and produced only small, non-systematic clusters). Thus the paper provides ROI/subject-level results but lacks a clear healthy-group whole-brain voxelwise task contrast required by the inclusion criteria.

This fMRI study investigates facial emotion perception (a social-related processing task) using a passive viewing task. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=27; mean age ~40, within 17–65). The authors report whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked analyses (within-group activation maps and contrasts such as faces vs. scrambled and emotional vs. neutral), thresholded and corrected (cluster-forming z>2.3, p<0.05), with within-group activation results for the control group described (complete within-group activations provided in the Supplementary Material) and illustrated in figures/tables. Results for the healthy/control group are therefore clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and uses task-based fMRI (not solely ROI or connectivity-only analyses). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

Study includes a healthy adult control group (n=25, mean age ~33) and reports task-based fMRI whole-brain analyses. The paradigm probes social-related processing (emotional sentence attribution; social communication/theory-of-mind domain). Group-level whole-brain results are reported (main task effects, group effects and Task×Group interaction) with FWE-corrected voxelwise maps and coordinate tables. The paper explicitly states healthy controls significantly activated the medial prefrontal cortex during the emotional task, indicating an identifiable healthy-group task activation map (reported via interaction and plotted activations). Thus it provides whole-brain, univariate task-evoked results attributable to a healthy adult sample and meets inclusion criteria.

Although the study used task-based fMRI of social reward and reports whole-brain, group-level activation maps, the sample includes both healthy and clinical participants (9 with current MDD) and all neuroimaging analyses are reported across the combined sample (n=27) or dimensionally with anhedonia/depression covariates. The paper does not present a separate whole-brain, univariate task activation map for a healthy/adult-only control group that is generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the criterion requiring at least one group-level whole-brain task map from a healthy adult group reported separately.

This peer-reviewed fMRI study experimentally manipulates social-cognitive processes (basal face processing, emotion recognition, affective Theory-of-Mind) using task-based event-related fMRI. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; mean age ~30) reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation results (single-group results at P<0.001 uncorrected are provided in Supplementary Tables S1–S4) and whole-brain group comparisons; although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain healthy-group task effects are clearly described. Thus it satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI of social processing, healthy adult group, and whole-brain univariate results). Note: sample size is small and clinical group present, but healthy-control whole-brain data are reported separately.

This study reports task-based whole-brain fMRI of social-related stimuli (positive social interaction, faces, erotica) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=14; mean age 28.2). Voxelwise, univariate whole-brain analyses (stimulus group × participant group × scan ANOVAs) are reported with mapwise-corrected clusters and Talairach coordinates (Tables 3–5) and simple-effects for control subjects are described, meeting the requirement to provide healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical results. The task assesses social-perception and social-affective constructs relevant to the review objective. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it should be included.

While the study uses fMRI on a social (Theory-of-Mind) task and includes a healthy adult control group (n=25, ages within 18–60), it does not clearly report a univariate whole-brain, voxelwise task activation map explicitly for the healthy/control group. Table 2 and the whole-brain results appear to present task contrasts without specifying they are healthy-group maps (likely combined sample or general task effects), and the between-group results are emphasized via ROI extractions and group comparisons. The paper therefore lacks a clearly identified, unmasked healthy-group whole-brain task effect (voxelwise map or coordinates explicitly attributed to HC), which fails the review’s required whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults: participants (n=20; age 18–45) completed a legal decision-making task probing responsibility and punishment (perception/understanding of others, moral/social cognition). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts and regressions with peak voxel coordinates and multiple-comparison correction (whole-brain results in Tables 1–4), not solely ROI or connectivity analyses. Healthy adult group results are reported separately and generalizable. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (task fMRI of social-related processing; healthy adult sample within age range; whole-brain group-level univariate maps reported). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adults (N=16, ages 18–26) that explicitly probes social-related processing: participants continuously tracked emotional expression (emotion task) in voices and music, engaging processes related to perception/understanding of others (medial SFG/ACC; theory-of-mind/empathy). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., emotion task > pitch task, voice > rest, music > rest), with cluster-corrected statistics, peak coordinates, figures, and ROI follow-ups. Results are reported for the healthy participant group and are generalizable within the adult range. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social attribution (People vs Bumper) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=17, ages 18–39). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts for the People - Bumper condition for controls (one-sample t-test group maps shown in Fig. 3 and peak coordinates/clusters reported in tables), and also provides between-group comparisons. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and include whole-brain activation clusters and coordinate tables, satisfying the requirement for univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes healthy adults).

While the study uses task fMRI of a social-related perspective-taking task and includes a healthy adult control group (n=20, ages within 17–65), it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level (healthy/control) task activation map. Second-level analyses were restricted to predefined prefrontal ROIs (medial/lateral prefrontal regions) rather than whole-brain voxelwise contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. The reported results emphasize ROI-based activations and group × condition interactions and seed-based functional connectivity; there is no clear univariate whole-brain healthy-group task effect (e.g., whole-brain within-group contrast for controls) presented. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain, univariate, group-level healthy-task activation map, this study should be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related (affective and cognitive Theory of Mind), (2) Sample consists of healthy adults (N=23) within the 17–65 range, (3) The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (AToM vs control and CToM vs control) with voxelwise thresholding and FDR cluster correction and provides tables/coordinates and figures of significant clusters, and (4) Not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore this study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although this fMRI study of physician–patient interaction uses healthy adult participants and probes social/empathy-related processing, the reported neuroimaging results are ROI-based (5 mm spheres derived a priori) with FWE correction performed within those ROIs. The paper does not present an unmasked, group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the review’s required whole-brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This is a single-case study of a patient with high-functioning ASD and developmental prosopagnosia, compared to control subjects. The full text does not clearly report a group-level, unmasked whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for healthy/control adults that is generalizable to the healthy adult population. The reported results focus on comparisons with the patient, specific regional activations (FG, OFA, left aSTS/MTG), and functional connectivity differences; these appear to be between-group contrasts and connectivity analyses rather than standalone whole-brain healthy-group task maps. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for a clearly reported healthy-group whole-brain univariate task activation map.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult (normal) subjects performing social-cognition tasks (attentional and attributional judgments about self-relevant/threatening material), fitting the review’s social-related constructs (perception/understanding of self/others). Group-level task activations are reported (named cortical and subcortical regions with Brodmann areas), indicating whole-brain univariate task-evoked results for the healthy group rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. Participant group is healthy adults; results are presented as generalizable within-group activations. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) are met. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study of moral reasoning (a social-cognition task). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=28, mean age ~31) reported separately. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy controls (one-sample analyses and pooled contrasts; results reported in Table 3 and Figure 2, FWE-corrected), not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This fMRI study examines mentalizing (Theory-of-Mind) during comprehension of literary fiction—directly addressing social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Participants were healthy adults (N=18; ages 18–27), meeting the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Mentalizing > Action and Action > Mentalizing) with correction for multiple comparisons and localized activations (aMPFC, rTPJ, etc.), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study also includes ROI analyses but does not rely solely on them. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers (mean age 29, range 22–38) investigating perception of others’ head turns — a social-attention / perception-of-others task. The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain analyses (gray-matter–masked full-volume and ROI-constrained analyses) with voxelwise results and coordinates (FWE-corrected p-values) and figures/tables described in the text. The sample consists of healthy adults and results are reported for that group. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and coordinate results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only connectivity or only patient groups) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of action observation/execution addressing perception and understanding of others’ applied force—a social perceptual process relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Participants: healthy adult sample (n=12, mean age 26) within 17–65. Methods: task-based fMRI with whole-brain, group-level, univariate GLM analyses (SPM12), voxelwise maps and conjunction analyses reported, thresholds and cluster coordinates described; cerebellar SUIT and whole-brain results provided. Results are presented as group-level task-evoked whole-brain activation maps and coordinates. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not between-group-only). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a resting-state study that manipulates participants’ belief about being observed; analyses focus on seed/network functional connectivity contrasts between resting scans (intra- and inter-network connectivity using nodes derived from Neurosynth). The paper does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation maps or coordinate tables from a task contrast for the healthy adult group. The review’s exclusion criteria explicitly disallow studies that report only resting-state or connectivity analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion requirement for a task-evoked whole-brain map.

Study includes a healthy adult control group (17 age- and IQ-matched controls) and uses fMRI during a social-related task (thinking about interpersonal interactions/self-related cognition). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM contrasts (social interactions > fixation) for the groups, with reported activation maps/locations and thresholding (p=0.001 uncorrected, extent 5 voxels) described for the control group. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults in the specified age range. The study is empirical, not limited to ROIs or resting-state/connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses fMRI during social tasks (SID, EFP) with a healthy control group aged 50–60 (within the 17–65 range), the reported whole-brain results are presented primarily for the combined sample or as ROI-based analyses. The paper notes whole-brain findings in supplemental tables, but does not clearly report an unmasked, group-level, voxelwise task activation map specifically for the healthy/control group alone. Several key findings rely on ROI small-volume correction and group comparisons (COC vs CTRL). Because the inclusion criteria require at least one univariate whole-brain task map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (or a healthy adult subgroup) and generalizable to healthy adults, this study does not meet that criterion.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social-related Theory-of-Mind task and includes a healthy control group, it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control participants. Analyses were restricted to ROI (small-volume) corrections and primarily report between-group contrasts (patients vs controls) and patient-focused regressions. The paper therefore lacks the required whole-brain, voxelwise healthy-group task activation map generalizable to healthy adults, violating the ‘Whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social cognition using ecological language-based stimuli (listening to film excerpts of social interactions) and directly targets social-related processing (theory of mind/attribution). It includes a healthy adult group (HC-S1, n=28; ages 18–65) and presents a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (INT > HIN) for the healthy controls, thresholded at p<0.05 FWE, with coordinates and cluster tables (Table 2) and figures. Healthy-group results are reported separately from the patient group, and whole-brain task activation maps and peak coordinates are clearly described. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, includes healthy adults within age range, empirical data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self- and other-reflection) and includes a healthy adult control group (21 HCs). The paper reports within-group, whole-brain univariate task effects for the healthy/control group (e.g., self > semantic and other > semantic activations in VMPFC, DMPFC, ACC, PCC, precuneus, etc.) using voxelwise FWE-corrected thresholds, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group task activations are clearly described. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This article is a non-empirical narrative review of semantic dementia (clinical, imaging, genetics, pathology) and does not report any original task-based fMRI experiment in healthy adults. It contains no group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation maps for a healthy adult sample, nor does it present separate healthy-group results from clinical comparisons. Therefore it fails multiple inclusion criteria (empirical fMRI data during social-related tasks; healthy adult participants; whole-brain voxelwise maps) and meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social learning about others’ preference similarity (social cognition: perception/understanding of others; affiliation/liking measures). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=25, mean age 25.1, range within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLMs, conjunctions, cluster-corrected contrasts) with peak MNI coordinates and cluster statistics for multiple contrasts and parametric modulators. The methods and results clearly describe univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy participant group. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not patient-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI study of social-related processing (self-referential task), includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; ages 31–58 within 17–65), and reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked activation maps for the healthy/control group (activation maps and whole-brain corrected results for controls are described and shown). Although the paper also includes a clinical schizophrenia group, control-group results are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, resting-state-only, or absence of healthy-group whole-brain results) are violated.

Although the study uses task fMRI of a social-related process (irony comprehension) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=15), the paper does not report an unambiguous, whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The manuscript primarily reports combined or across-participant activations and between-group (control vs. schizophrenia) contrasts; control-group results are noted as ‘previously published’ rather than provided here as an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group map. Because the review requires a within-group, whole-brain, task-evoked statistical map for the healthy adults, this study fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI task study of social communication (perception of different laughter types) in healthy adults (N=18, mean age 26, right-handed, no neurological/psychiatric history), fitting the review’s social-related constructs. The paper reports group-level univariate, voxelwise task contrasts and conjunction analyses (e.g., JOY>TICKLE, TAU>TICKLE, TIC>JOY) with whole-brain results presented in tables of coordinates and figures; random-effects second-level analyses are described and thresholded, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state only, and results are clearly reported for the healthy control group. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it should be included.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing that includes a healthy adult control group (n=9, mean age 37) and uses a facial-emotion task, the paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group. Results are described primarily as between-group (VCFS vs controls) differences (Table 1), and the text does not present or tabulate within-group whole-brain (control) contrasts or coordinates that are generalizable to healthy adults. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring a clearly identified healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical map. Therefore the study must be excluded.

Although this is an fMRI study of a social-related task (dynamic face processing) and includes a healthy adult control group (N=21, ages within 18–65), the paper only reports between-group (schizophrenia patients vs controls) whole-brain contrasts and group-difference maps. The manuscript does not present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (e.g., faces>baseline) clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone or report within-group healthy-control activation maps/coordinates. Therefore it does not meet the requirement to provide a healthy-group whole-brain task effect and must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: 1) Task is social-related (observation of others’ hand actions with risk/safety; relates to social cognition/perception of others and affect). 2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants aged 18.1–22.8 (within 17–65). 3) The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (risk-taking vs. safe) analyzed with SPM and presents voxelwise results, coordinates, figures, and conjunction analyses generalizable to the healthy group. 4) It is empirical fMRI work (not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related Theory of Mind task (animated interacting shapes). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=20; ages 22–56) reported separately. The paper presents whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (ToM vs random-motion) with corrected statistical thresholds and reports group-level Talairach coordinates and cluster sizes for the healthy subjects (Tables and figures), i.e., an unmasked, generalizable healthy-group task effect. The study is empirical, not ROI- or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study reports fMRI task-evoked whole-brain analyses and includes a typically developing (control) group, but participants are adolescents (mean ages ~15.8–17.0; ranges include many <17). The review requires a healthy adult group aged 17–65 or a separately reported adult subgroup; this study does not provide a healthy adult sample or separate adult-only results. Therefore it fails the sample age inclusion criterion.

The study is an fMRI investigation of empathy for pain (a social cognition task: perception/understanding of others). Participants include a healthy young adult group (ages 20–30) within the 17–65 range, and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (pain>no pain and pain>baseline) with whole-brain FWE-corrected maps and tables. Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches, and healthy-group task activation maps are reported and described. Although the sample also includes an older group (65–75), the study includes and reports results for a healthy adult subgroup within the required age range and provides univariate whole-brain task activation maps, satisfying inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI hyperscanning study of joint attention (a social cognition task) in healthy adults (N=65; mean age ~22). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., JA > control; IJA vs RJA; volition effects) with thresholding and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides figures and tables of activations. The study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results and includes whole-brain maps/generalizable healthy-group effects. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The healthy/control group comprises adolescents (controls age range 12.08–18.17, mean 15.06) rather than adults; no separate healthy adult subgroup (age 17–65) is analyzed or reported. Although the study uses task fMRI of social processing and provides whole-brain, univariate control-group activation maps, it fails the sample-age inclusion criterion requiring a healthy adult participant group (17–65). Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study (NeuroImage 2014) investigating social cognition (Theory of Mind; Why/How task) in healthy adult participants (right-handed adults, ages 19–38). Group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts are reported (e.g., Why > How; Belief > Photo) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak coordinates presented in tables. Healthy adult results are reported separately and are generalizable to the healthy group. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and includes original task-evoked whole-brain activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social/affiliation task in healthy adult women (ages 22–45) and reports group-level task contrasts (own child vs. own dog, own vs. unfamiliar, etc.), the statistical inference is conducted using a priori ROIs with small-volume correction (SVC). The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task activation map or whole-brain results that are clearly generalizable to healthy adults independent of the ROI masks. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group, and this manuscript reports primarily ROI/SVC-based results (no clear whole-brain, unmasked healthy-group activation map), it does not meet the whole-brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of self–other processing (a social cognition task: Perception/Understanding of Self and Others). It includes a typically developing (TD) healthy control group with group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation results reported for the healthy group (within-group TD contrasts reported with coordinates and figures: e.g., Self>Letter activations in MPFC, LIFG, LMTG, precuneus). Although the paper also includes an ASD clinical group, the TD (healthy) group results are reported separately. Participant ages in the TD group are reported (mean 27.3, range 16–34); the vast majority are adults and the reported group-level results are generalizable to healthy adults (note: one TD participant is age 16, but the group-level map is dominated by adult participants). Therefore the study meets the review’s fMRI, social-task, healthy-group, and whole-brain reporting criteria and is eligible for inclusion.

This study used task-based fMRI during social-cognitive processing (affective ToM, emotion recognition, neutral face processing) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=18 males).
