The paper reports group-level task-evoked activation for the healthy/control group (e.g., bilateral STS and inferior prefrontal gyrus activations with coordinates and thresholds) from whole-brain analyses (P<0.001 uncorrected) alongside ROI results for amygdala. Results for the healthy group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper also includes connectivity analyses but does not rely on them exclusively. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

While the study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants performing social interactions (cooperation/competition) and reports spatial component maps from group-ICA, it does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., GLM contrast or main effect map) for the healthy group. The analyses are primarily data-driven (gICA and ISC) and connectivity/alignment-focused rather than standard voxelwise task activation contrasts. Therefore it fails the requirement for a whole-brain univariate task activation map and must be excluded.

The fMRI task in this study probes basic visual motion processing (moving vs stationary concentric rings) and mid-temporal/motion-sensitive cortex activation, not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Although the paper includes healthy adult control groups and reports whole-brain task-evoked activations and ROI contrasts, the experimental paradigm and reported contrasts are not about social constructs required by the meta-analysis objective. Therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion of using fMRI during a social-related task and must be excluded.

The provided full-text content is only a website privacy/cookie policy, not the article itself. There is no methodological, participant, or results information to verify that the study (1) used task-based fMRI for a social-related task, (2) included healthy adult participants (age 17–65), or (3) reported group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation maps for a healthy/control group. Because the inclusion criteria require clear whole-brain task-evoked results and the supplied full text lacks any empirical details, I cannot confirm any required criterion. Therefore the study must be excluded from the review based on insufficient information in the provided full text.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (interpersonal social touch) in healthy adult participants (N=40 heterosexual males, mean age 25.8). The design is a within-subject, placebo-controlled pharmaco-fMRI task manipulating social context; behavioral and neural results are reported. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation results (whole-brain contrasts and coordinates, PFWE-corrected clusters, with supplementary tables), clearly from the healthy sample. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and meets the age and sample criteria. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related (voice perception/social perception of others). (2) Includes a healthy adult control group (8 male controls, mean age 27.1) with results reported separately. (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast for the healthy/control group (random-effects analysis, voice vs non-voice, P < 0.001 corrected; identified STS peaks and figures/tables). (4) Empirical fMRI data in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, healthy subgroup reported, participants within 17–65). Therefore include for meta-analysis of healthy adult social task fMRI.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test) in healthy adult participants (18–40 years). The paper reports group-level, univariate task-evoked activation maps for the healthy/control group: a one-sample ToM>gender contrast within the placebo (healthy) condition and paired contrasts, with tables of coordinates and explicit whole-brain results (exploratory analyses at P<0.001 uncorrected) in addition to ROI/SVC results. The sample is within the required adult age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (emotion processing and Theory of Mind) that reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain univariate contrasts (EMOTION vs GENDER) using SPM2 and random-effects analysis. A healthy adult control group (n=14, mean age 28.4 ± 8.3) is reported separately, with within-group activation maps, coordinates, and figures/tables describing voxelwise activations. The tasks and contrasts clearly index social-related processes (EP, FToM, EToM). The study does not rely solely on ROIs or connectivity/resting-state analyses, and it provides generalizable healthy-group whole-brain results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (charitable donation/altruism; constructs include affiliation/attachment, moral decision-making). Sample: 19 healthy adult participants (mean age 28.2, right-handed), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses and contrasts (e.g., VTA, ventral/dorsal striatum, subgenual area, orbitofrontal, anterior PFC) with coordinates and figures, generalizable to healthy adults. Results are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts; whole-brain task-evoked maps and contrasts for the healthy group are clearly described. The study is primary empirical work with original fMRI data in healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception of dynamic emotional facial expressions and social situations). It includes a separate healthy adult (neurotypical, NT) group (Study 1: NT n=21; Study 2: NT n=30) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain voxelwise analyses via a searchlight MVPA (whole-brain accuracy maps with FWE-corrected clusters reported in Table 6 and Fig.5) and also notes univariate GLM analyses (univariate results reported in supplementary material). The task is clearly social (emotion/valence attribution) and involves healthy adults within the 17–65 range. Therefore the study meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI of social processing, healthy adult group reported separately, whole-brain voxelwise results provided).

Although the study includes healthy adult control participants (n=14) and uses task-based fMRI during a social face-processing task, it does not report a clear, unmasked whole-brain, group-level task activation map that is identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. The paper presents a whole-group (n=28) faces>houses whole-brain map, between-group contrasts (NT>AS), and ROI (amygdala) analyses for the control group, but no standalone voxelwise healthy-control group map or coordinates for a within-group (controls only) faces>houses contrast. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map clearly attributable to the healthy adult group, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence requirement and must be excluded.

This article is a narrative review synthesizing neuroimaging findings and theories about social brain development and autism rather than reporting original fMRI data from a healthy adult sample. It summarizes multiple empirical studies (some by the authors) but does not present new, whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked statistical maps from a healthy adult group that are generalizable; nor does it provide primary methods/participant details for an original healthy adult fMRI dataset. As a non-empirical/review paper, it therefore fails the inclusion criterion requiring original fMRI whole-brain healthy-adult task activation maps and meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers without original fMRI data.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=23, ages 19–32) that uses a task-based paradigm (self-paced reading of a literary text with trial-by-trial suspense ratings). The authors report group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (reading>rating contrast and a parametric suspense regressor) with cluster-level FWE correction and tables/coordinates of significant activations, plus ROI and PPI follow-ups. Although the paradigm is naturalistic (reading), the paper explicitly examines social-cognitive processes (mentalizing/theory-of-mind, TPJ and medial frontal cortex) and interprets suspense-related activations in terms of perception/understanding of others, fitting the review’s social-related constructs. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, clinical-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20, age 21–32) that probes social-related processing (personal prayer vs secular controls, targeting theory-of-mind/social cognition). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses and contrasts (Tables 2–4, figures) with results thresholded at p<0.05 FDR-corrected, showing activations in medial PFC, TPJ, temporopolar region and precuneus. It is not limited to ROI- or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly reported. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI of a social-related construct (empathy) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=14; ages 22–47). The paper presents within-group (one-sample t-test) whole-brain, voxelwise activation maps for the healthy/control group (reported with voxel-level p<0.001 and cluster correction, results shown in tables/figures and described in text). Healthy-group results are reported separately from the patient group. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI experiment of verbal irony (social communication/perception of others) with twenty healthy adult participants (mean age 22, right-handed) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Ironic > Literal) with cluster-wise FDR-corrected results and voxelwise coordinates (Table 3 and figures), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI and PPI analyses are also reported, whole-brain activation maps are clearly presented and described for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only; includes task-evoked whole-brain maps; healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore the study qualifies for inclusion.

Insufficient evidence in the provided full text to meet key inclusion criteria. The study’s participants are mothers of preterm infants (a specialized group), and it is not clear whether there is a separate healthy/adult control group reported or that results for a healthy adult group are presented independently. The provided content contains references and bibliographic material but no methods/results showing an unmasked, group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation map for a healthy/control adult group (only citations are visible). Because the review requires clear whole-brain, univariate healthy-group task maps generalizable to healthy adults, and this information is not available in the supplied text, the study cannot be confirmed as eligible and must be excluded.

The study uses task-based fMRI with a social perception paradigm (videos of cooperative vs noncooperative interactions). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=19) and reports within-group contrasts for controls (C+ > C–) with whole-brain, voxelwise second-level analyses (FDR/FWE-corrected) described in the text and figures/tables. Results for the healthy group are reported separately and are generalizable (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only). Age details are not explicitly listed in the provided excerpt, but participants are described as matched adults and typical clinical/control recruitment implies adult ages; therefore inclusion is appropriate. Meets all meta-analysis inclusion criteria (task fMRI, healthy adult group, whole-brain univariate maps reported).

This study reports event-related fMRI of a social gaze-processing task and includes a separate neurologically normal (healthy) control group (n=9; mean age 23.4 years) alongside an autism group. The paper presents group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate activation maps and voxelwise contrasts (e.g., incongruent > congruent) for the neurologically normal subjects, with tables of stereotaxic coordinates and figures illustrating the activations (STS and other regions). The task probes social cognition (perception/understanding of others via gaze), satisfying the construct requirement. Although one control participant is reported at age 15.5, the healthy group is otherwise adult and reported separately; the study therefore provides healthy-adult whole-brain task activation maps suitable for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social reflection: self- and other-judgments) in healthy adults (n=22, mean age 37.4, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (surface-based cortical analyses and Monte Carlo cluster correction) for the SR > AL, S > AL, and O > AL contrasts with coordinates and cluster statistics (Table 2 and figures). Healthy-group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI or resting-state/seed connectivity results; it provides whole-brain activation maps and tables of coordinates meeting the inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be included.

Although the study used an fMRI social-task and included a healthy adult control group (n=14, ages within 17–65), it does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Within-group healthy results are reported via ROI/SVC analyses, and the paper’s whole-brain analyses appear limited to between-group contrasts (exploratory uncorrected results for ‘social>non-social’ healthy>manic and manic>healthy). Therefore it fails the requirement to report an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect generalizable to healthy adults. Other inclusion criteria (task type and sample) are met, but the absence of a healthy-group whole-brain activation map mandates exclusion.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related — an emotional face discrimination task probing perception/understanding of others; (2) Sample comprises 38 healthy adults (mean age 27.5), within 17–65; (3) Reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrast (FACES>OBJECTS) with SPM t-maps, cluster-level FWE correction, tables/figures and coordinates; (4) Not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study includes a healthy, age-appropriate control group (n=11; mean age 18.7 within the 17–65 range) and uses task-based fMRI of face encoding (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts for the control group (subsequent memory/Dm effects) with tables of significant clusters and coordinates (e.g., Table 2) and voxelwise whole-brain analyses corrected for multiple comparisons. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately from the clinical FXS group. The study is empirical and provides task-evoked whole-brain activation maps for a social-related task, meeting inclusion criteria.

While the study uses fMRI with a social inference task and includes a healthy control group, it does not report a clear group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked map for the healthy/control group. The reported whole-brain results focus on Group×Stimulus interactions and post hoc between-group simple effects (PTSD vs controls), and ROI analyses use masks defined from an independent dataset. No unmasked one-sample or within-control-group whole-brain activation map (e.g., Why>How within controls) is presented or described as a healthy-group task effect generalizable to healthy adults. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation map for the healthy/control group, this paper does not meet all required inclusion criteria and should be excluded.

Although the study uses task fMRI probing social interaction and includes a healthy control group with adult participants, the reported healthy-group results are derived from ROI-masked analyses (frontopolar, IFG, temporal poles, TPJ) and thresholded within that a priori mask. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group (nor report whole-brain corrected healthy-group effects outside the ROI). Because the review requires at least one whole-brain (voxelwise) healthy-group task activation map and studies reporting only ROI analyses are excluded, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

Although this is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants using social stimuli (fearful faces and scenes) and reports group-level effects, the paper’s primary statistical inferences are ROI-based (amygdala) with significance corrected within an amygdala mask; no unmasked, whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation map (whole-brain corrected or unmasked group contrast) is reported as a healthy-group task effect. The connectivity results are seed-based and brainstem ROI–restricted, which do not substitute for a whole-brain univariate task activation map. Therefore it fails the requirement for reporting at least one whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical map for the healthy adult group.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy young adults using a social attribution task (perception of human-like interactions among shapes), clearly a social-cognition paradigm. The abstract and results describe group-level, voxelwise task activations across multiple brain regions (FFA, amygdala, temporal pole, medial PFC, IFG, STS), indicating whole-brain univariate effects for the healthy/control group rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. Participants are healthy adults within the eligible age range. The study is empirical with original fMRI data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI of social cognition (trustworthiness judgments of faces); includes a healthy adult control group (n=18, mean age 32.2) with results reported separately; reports within-group whole-brain task activation maps and tables of coordinates for the control group (trustworthy/untrustworthy vs baseline and contrasts), generalizable to healthy adults. Although a clinical XXY group is present, healthy-group whole-brain results are clearly described. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or missing healthy-group whole-brain maps) are violated.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (n=16) and uses an fMRI social gaze task, the paper reports psychophysiological interaction (PPI) seed-based connectivity analyses (SC and LC) and PPI whole-brain connectivity maps. It does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group (the manuscript focuses on connectivity and between-group PPI contrasts; any ‘whole-brain’ results described are connectivity/PPI results or between-group contrasts). Per the meta-analysis criteria, studies that report only seed-based/effective connectivity (e.g., PPI) without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map must be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (virtual reality attribution task) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=14; ages within 18–45). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation contrasts for the healthy comparison group (e.g., Emotion vs Control; Neutral-Control), with voxelwise results presented as coordinates, cluster sizes, and statistical thresholds (uncorrected p<0.001, cluster >12 voxels). Results for the healthy group are reported separately from the bipolar patient group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults, reports whole-brain maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task fMRI during a social trust game and includes a healthy adult control group (20 males, ages 18–50). However, although an exploratory whole-brain, voxel-wise analysis is reported, the paper only describes between-group (control > patient) differences from that whole-brain analysis. The manuscript does not report an unmasked, within-group (healthy/control) whole-brain task-evoked statistical map or main-effect contrast generalizable to healthy adults; primary imaging results are ROI-based. Per inclusion criteria, a healthy-group whole-brain activation map is required. Because only ROI results and between-group whole-brain contrasts are provided, the paper fails the whole-brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20; mean age 20.65) that reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (random-effects second-level SPM8 analyses, cluster-corrected results). The tasks explicitly probe event simulation including situational understanding and future prediction; stimuli included social scenarios (≈42.7%) and the authors conducted analyses splitting social vs non-social trials, replicating key activations. Reported contrasts (e.g., Exp–Imp, Ftr–Exp) identify whole-brain activations linked to social-cognition-related regions (MPFC, TPJ, TP), satisfying the review’s definition of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The paper is empirical, uses healthy adults within the 17–65 range, and provides whole-brain univariate maps (reported thresholds/coordinates). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task fMRI with a social-affective (empathic fear) film and reports results for a healthy adult control group (ages 22–39), it does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. The analyses focus on network cohesion index (NCI) dynamic connectivity measures, ROI/network-based comparisons, and time-series statistics; activity comparisons used averaged network node signals rather than voxelwise whole-brain contrasts or statistical maps. Therefore the paper fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy-group whole-brain task activation map (voxelwise) generalizable to healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social cognition (affective ToM, emotion recognition, neutral face processing) including a matched healthy adult control group. Whole-brain, univariate task-evoked results are reported (main effect of task and task × group interactions) with tables/figures of activation and coordinates, and additional group-level analyses are provided in the supplementary materials. Healthy controls are adults and results for controls are separable from patient data. The paper therefore meets the meta-analysis criteria of fMRI during a social-related task, inclusion of a healthy adult group, and provision of whole-brain task activation evidence generalizable to healthy adults.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind and empathy) in a healthy adult sample (N=76 college students, ages 17–21). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation maps obtained via SPM with RFT correction (αRFT ≤ 0.05) and describes pooled-condition (PCon) whole-brain results used in subsequent analyses. Results are not limited to ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group effects are clearly reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (20 registered voters, mean ages ~35, within 17–65) that uses a social-related task (viewing faces of presidential candidates; perception/understanding of others, group membership). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task effects (faces vs. rest produced widespread occipital and inferior temporal activations) and multiple voxelwise contrasts with thresholding and tables of MNI coordinates (cluster Z>2.3, p<.05 corrected). Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses and are reported for the healthy adult sample. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social judgment/feedback paradigm (social acceptance/rejection), meeting the social-related task criterion. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=20; mean age 28.15, SD 8.62) with within-group results reported separately. Whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses were conducted and thresholded using voxel and cluster-level correction (pFWE-equivalent), and within-group activation maps for controls (e.g., ventral striatum, anterior insula, medial prefrontal cortex) are described in text and figures. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore the paper provides qualifying whole-brain healthy-group task activation data appropriate for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (n=121 for imaging; ages 18–35). Participants completed two social-cognitive tasks (emotional perspective-taking and emotion attribution) during fMRI. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (emotion perspective-taking > shape match; emotion attribution > gender match) using FWE-corrected thresholds, and subsequent whole-brain regression analyses relating methylation to task-evoked BOLD activity; significant clusters (STS, fusiform, IFG) are reported for the healthy sample. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state only, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (approachability judgments from faces) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=24; mean age within 17–65) and reports group-level whole-brain univariate activation contrasts for the healthy/control group (approachability > gender) with peak coordinates and cluster-corrected p-values. Although the paper also includes a clinical schizophrenia group, the healthy group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper does more (connectivity analyses), but it also provides the required whole-brain task-evoked maps/tables for the control group rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social/emotional face-matching task (Emotion Match vs Shape Match), which is a social-related construct (social communication/perception of others). It includes a healthy adult comparison group (N=12, mean age ~32, within 17–65). The paper presents whole-brain, group-level univariate activation results for the healthy group (within-group one-sample t-tests and Emotion Match > Shape Match contrasts; Table 1 and whole-brain maps reported; random-effects ANOVA and voxelwise thresholds described). Results are not ROI-only and include coordinate tables and figures generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study (combined EEG–fMRI) of social processing (minimal-group membership and emotion perception) in healthy adult participants (N=20, mean age 23.4). The paper reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain univariate analyses (with voxel- and cluster-level thresholds) and provides coordinates and tables of activations (e.g., mPFC, right STS/TPJ) that are clearly from the healthy/control group. The task is social (group categorization/emotion processing) and results are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, clinical-only samples, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (joint attention; self vs. other) in healthy adults (n=24, ages 20–34). It uses task-based, univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., self>other, JA>NJA) and reports group-level activation coordinates and statistical results (MNI coordinates, cluster stats). Although several effects were reported after small-volume correction within a priori ROIs, the paper provides voxelwise group-level task activation maps/contrasts for the healthy sample that are generalizable and clearly described. All inclusion criteria are met (task-based fMRI, healthy adult sample, group-level voxelwise results reported).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception and understanding of others via emotional facial expressions and face identity in VSTM). The sample comprises healthy adults (N=35, mean age 29, in the 17–65 range). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (random-effects ANCOVA; FDR-corrected voxelwise results, Talairach coordinates and cluster tables) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Results for the healthy control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not resting-state, not connectivity-only, not limited-age or non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (learning facts about people vs. buildings/hammers) in healthy adults (N=12, ages 20–32). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task contrasts and conjunction analyses (person > building AND person > hammer), with cluster-size correction and Talairach-space maps; results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps and ROI-aggregated responses. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and healthy-group task activation effects are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=304, ages 18–22) using a social task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) examining neural responses to unreciprocated cooperation. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (e.g., CD>CC contrasts) with cluster-level FWE correction and presents whole-brain results (figures/tables and supplementary figures), as well as coordinate tables for activated regions. Results are reported for the healthy sample and are generalizable within the healthy adult population. The study therefore meets the inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI of social processing, healthy adult participants within age range, and at least one univariate whole-brain group-level task activation map. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (viewing dynamic facial emotional expressions) in healthy adults (fMRI N=40, mean age ~30.5). It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (dynamic > static) with voxelwise results and tables of MNI coordinates (Table 1) and figures, clearly from the healthy/control group. The task is social-emotion perception (relevant construct). Results are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor to special/clinical-only samples. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although the study used task fMRI with a healthy (TD) adult control group and investigated social-emotional face processing, the reported fMRI results are presented as amygdala ROI analyses (statistical thresholds corrected within the amygdala) and between-group contrasts. The paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level (healthy/control) task activation map or whole-brain voxelwise contrasts generalizable to the healthy adult population. Inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain, group-level univariate task map for the healthy group. Because the fMRI results are ROI-restricted and the healthy-group whole-brain effects are not provided, the study fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: the study used task-based fMRI during a social-related task (dynamic facial emotion perception/recognition). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (mean age ~22) reported separately from the familial-risk group. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation/deactivation maps for the study groups (e.g., Figure 2, subject- and group-level analyses using FLAME with cluster correction, and reported coordinates/clusters), which satisfy the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although additional ROI and PPI analyses are present, whole-brain within-group task maps for the healthy/control group are clearly reported. Age range and empirical design are appropriate. Therefore the study should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study using an interactive social task (Cyberball) probing social exclusion (a social-related construct). The sample comprises 21 healthy adult participants (age 20–37), with results reported for the healthy group. The paper provides group-level, univariate, task-evoked whole-brain contrasts (e.g., “not receiving ESE > receiving INCL”), including whole-brain tables of coordinates (Tables S3 and S4) and figures, which meet the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses, and it reports within-group effects generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study uses task-based fMRI with social-cognition paradigms (empathic and forgivability judgments). It includes a healthy adult comparison group (14 healthy adults, ages approx. 30.5 ± 8.8) with results for the healthy group reported separately. Whole-brain, voxelwise SPM analyses are reported for within-group task effects in the healthy comparison sample (activation maps and coordinates for empathic and forgivability judgments are described, with thresholds and Talairach coordinates), satisfying the requirement for group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and reports original fMRI data. It does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses, and the healthy-group task effects are not limited to a narrowly defined subgroup. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults.

This study meets all inclusion criteria. It uses task-based fMRI probing social-related processing (mirror neuron system; perception/understanding of others/actions). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (college students aged ~20) with separate groups (alexithymic and non-alexithymic) and no neurological/psychiatric diagnoses. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation maps and one-sample tests for each group (and a conjunction), with tables of MNI coordinates and corrected thresholds, making results generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and reports original whole-brain task-evoked data, so it should be included.

This study uses task-based fMRI to examine perception and anticipation of another person’s actions (perception and understanding of others), a social-related construct. Participants are healthy adult badminton players (novice to international level), and group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts are reported (random-effects shots–mctrl contrast, familywise-error thresholding) with peak coordinates and figures. Results are reported for the healthy adult sample and are generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup). The paper also provides whole-brain tables/figures rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=41, ages 18–37) investigating social-related processing (empathy/Theory of Mind). It reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (e.g., PP>PPC, EP>EPC, AllPain>AllNoPain) with corrected p-values and peak coordinates (Tables/Figures), and uses random-effects analyses generalizable to healthy adults. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and not limited to a special subgroup. The paper therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition/empathy (perception and understanding of others) in healthy adults (n=60, ages 18–60). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (human negative > neutral; animal negative > neutral) with SPM2 random-effects analysis, FWE-corrected statistical maps, and MNI coordinates/tables for activations. Results for the healthy participant groups are reported separately (within-group one-sample and paired t-tests, and between-group contrasts). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this is an fMRI study of social gaze in healthy adult participants, the authors report only ROI-based analyses (amygdala and inferior occipital gyrus) and do not provide any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (main effect or within-group contrast) for the healthy sample in the text, tables, figures, or supplement. Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirement for whole-brain evidence and must be excluded.

This is an original task-based fMRI study that includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; ages 17–34). The task is social-related: participants viewed images of another person performing body-checking actions and were instructed to imagine performing the actions, engaging self-referential and social-cognitive processes (mentalizing/mirroring). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain activation maps/analyses for the healthy control group (within-group contrast: body-checking vs neutral), with cluster-corrected maps and coordinates (e.g., anteromedial PFC x=12 y=53 z=2; parietal/fusiform activations) clearly described. The study is not ROI-only, nor connectivity/resting-state only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain task effects generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Study reports task fMRI in a social-related paradigm (perception of others’ dynamic vs. static facial expressions). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13, mean age 24.3, range within 17–65) with results reported separately from the ASD group. The paper provides within-group whole-brain univariate contrasts for the control group (dynamic > static), thresholded with multiple-comparison correction across the whole brain, and describes activation maps/tables for the control group. Although the study also reports patient vs. control interactions and DCM, it explicitly presents unmasked, generalizable healthy-group task activation maps, satisfying the meta-analysis’ whole-brain evidence requirement. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This study used task-based fMRI of a social judgment (approachability) task and included a healthy adult control group (N=33, mean age ~36.5). The authors report whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (main effect of condition and within-group contrasts) and present within-group activation results and figures/tables (supplementary materials) that include the control group. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity analyses and healthy-group task activation maps are described separately from clinical groups. Therefore the paper meets the review’s requirements for fMRI social-task data in healthy adults with whole-brain task-evoked results.

The study includes a clinical BPD group and healthy controls and uses fMRI during social-cognitive tasks, but the available full text/abstract does not clearly report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task-evoked activation map specifically for the healthy/control group that is generalizable to healthy adults. The abstract reports between-group differences and main effects in the BPD group and notes regions where controls showed greater activation, but it is unclear whether separate within-group whole-brain statistical maps for controls were reported (as opposed to between-group contrasts). Also the full text is not accessible here to verify reporting of healthy-group voxelwise results or that the healthy sample falls within the 17–65 range. Because at least one inclusion criterion (clear whole-brain healthy-group task activation map) cannot be confirmed, the study must be excluded.

This article is a non-empirical review (Japanese-language review) describing functional neuroimaging approaches and summarizing findings; it does not present original fMRI data or report group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from a healthy adult sample. As such it fails the requirement for original whole-brain task activation results in healthy adults. It also matches the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers without original fMRI data. Therefore it should be excluded from the meta-analysis.

The study uses task fMRI of emotion recognition (a social cognition task) and includes a healthy adult control group (ages within range). However, the paper does not report an univariate, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group alone that is generalizable to healthy adults. The reported whole-brain results are between-group contrasts (HCs > SZs, SZs > HCs), group-by-condition interactions, and ROI (amygdala) analyses. There are no clearly-described, unmasked within-group (healthy control) main-effect or emotion>baseline maps presented in the text/tables that would qualify as a healthy-group whole-brain activation map. Because the study reports mainly between-group contrasts and ROI findings without a distinct whole-brain healthy-group task map, it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy-group whole-brain univariate result.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (face emotion discrimination) in a community sample of healthy adults (n=30, mean age ~31, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task-evoked maps and contrasts (e.g., EE vs. baseline, EE vs. EI) analyzed in SPM8, with tables of coordinates and cluster statistics across all participants and within-group one-sample t-tests. Results for the healthy participants are reported and generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social-related Theory-of-Mind task and includes a healthy control group of adults (age range overlaps 17–65), the paper reports only between-group contrasts (low-risk controls > high-risk offspring) and does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map or main effect for the healthy/control group alone. Per the review’s inclusion criteria, a clearly identified whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked map is required. Therefore it fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

This is an original fMRI study in healthy adults (n=24 analyzed; ages 21–40) investigating political/social attitude processing using an Implicit Association Test with faces/names of politicians—clearly a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain analyses (SPM2, random-effects), presents voxelwise contrasts, tables of coordinates, figures, and uses FDR correction for whole-brain results; results are generalizable to healthy adults and not restricted to an atypical subgroup. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain task-evoked maps and contrasts for the healthy group are provided. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social perception (observation of touch and empathy-related processing) in healthy adults (N=22, analyzed N≈20; age range 23–39). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., touch observation > control, masked with real touch > rest) with family-wise error (FWE) corrected results and peak coordinates in Table 1 and figures. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported clearly. The study does not rely solely on ROI, resting-state, or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (TD, ages 18–34) and uses task fMRI of social/mentalizing processing, it does NOT report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. The primary analyses use spatially-constrained ICA and temporal-sorting to derive network/component β-weights and component spatial maps; task effects are reported as component-level modulation (Δβ) rather than voxelwise SPM contrasts. The paper therefore lacks the required univariate, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map (reported voxelwise or as coordinate tables) specified in inclusion criterion 3, so it must be excluded.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (Theory of Mind using the Frith-Happé animations). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=23; ages 19–56) reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses for the healthy/NT group (one-sample t-tests, whole-brain ANOVA, voxelwise contrasts ToM>Baseline and ToM>RD, with coordinates, figures, and supplementary whole-brain results), not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. The task is task-based (not resting-state) and maps are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study focuses on adolescents with traumatic brain injury and (if present) healthy control participants are adolescents, not adults. The review requires at least one group of healthy adult participants aged 17–65 reported separately. This study does not include a healthy adult sample in the required age range, so it fails the sample inclusion criterion. Even if whole-brain fMRI results are reported, the absence of a qualifying healthy adult group excludes it from the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24, mean age 26.6) that investigates multimodal perception of social signals (emotional voice and face) — clearly a social-related task (social communication/perception). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (conjunction (AV > A) AND (AV > V)), thresholding, and tables/coordinates of significant activations (see Table 1 and voxelwise analyses described), so whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps for the healthy group are provided and generalizable. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy sample are reported. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of emotion/social-related processing in healthy adults (N=19, mean age 27.7), using a task where IAPS emotional images preceded action/shape trials. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (both ROI and whole-brain analyses with cluster-level FWE correction and coordinate tables/figures) clearly from the healthy sample. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and not limited to between-group contrasts. Participants fall within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study including a healthy adult control group (n=13, mean age 34.5 within 17–65). The task probes social-related processes (self-evaluation and evaluation of an intimate other — constructs: perception/understanding of self and others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate activation maps and coordinates for the healthy/control group (e.g., SELF>lexical, OTHER>lexical, conjunction, SELF>OTHER) that are clearly described and suitable for meta-analysis. It does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses and gives whole-brain contrasts for the healthy sample. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study of theory-of-mind (false belief) in healthy adults (N=34; age 20–28). It uses a social-related task (reasoning about others' mental states) and reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (ROMS vs CTRL) with statistical activation maps and peak coordinates (Table 1). Healthy participants are within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is empirical and provides univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only sample, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult men examining social cognition (fear recognition and response to direct vs. averted gaze). The methods include task-evoked fMRI during face/gaze viewing and report group-level activation differences in regions (amygdala, fusiform gyrus, anterior superior temporal cortex) related to direct versus averted gaze. The study includes healthy adult participants (control/normal fear scorers) and reports univariate task-evoked activation contrasts (voxelwise group effects) between gaze conditions and between groups; these provide whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. While the paper also includes connectivity analyses, it additionally reports univariate activation results for the healthy groups, satisfying inclusion criteria. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for inclusion.

The paper’s title and focus are on schizophrenia out-patients (a clinical sample). The full text was not accessible (site error), so I cannot verify that a separate healthy adult control group (age 17–65) is reported nor confirm that the paper provides group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation maps for healthy participants. Because inclusion requires explicit healthy-group whole-brain task results, and this cannot be confirmed from the available information, the study does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria and should be excluded.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social processing and includes a healthy adult control group (TD; ages within 17–65) reported separately, it does not report any group-level univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy/control group. The authors explicitly state they focused on an a priori ROI (arMPFC) and did not perform whole-brain or functional connectivity analyses due to signal loss; results are reported as ROI parameter estimates rather than voxelwise whole-brain contrasts or coordinate tables for the healthy group. This violates the inclusion requirement for at least one whole-brain task-evoked map from healthy adults, so the study must be excluded.

This study reports task-evoked whole-brain, univariate fMRI results for a social cognition task (emotional and non-emotional judgments of faces). It includes a healthy adult control group (age range within 18–65) and reports within-group activation maps and contrasts (e.g., emotion>scrambled, age>scrambled, emotion>age) with whole-brain voxelwise statistical testing (cluster-level FWE correction) and tables/figures of coordinates. Although clinical groups are included, healthy-control results are reported separately and are generalizable. The paper also provides supplementary material with within-group maps. It therefore meets inclusion criteria: social-related task, healthy adult sample with separable results, and whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or absence of healthy-group whole-brain map) are violated.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (direct vs averted gaze using a virtual‑reality social interaction). It includes a separately reported healthy adult control group (n=16, mean age ~30, within 17–65). The paper reports group‑level, univariate whole‑brain task-evoked analyses for controls (within-group contrasts and whole‑brain results described in text and Table 3 and illustrated in figures), not only ROI or connectivity-only findings. Results for controls (e.g., DMPFC, TPJ, temporal pole activations) are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, outside age range, or non-empirical) are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (10 right-handed adult males) using a task involving humor appreciation (viewing funny vs. non-funny cartoons), which qualifies as social-related processing (social communication/perception). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (univariate SPM regression and contrasts) with coordinates, cluster statistics, and figures (e.g., Talairach coordinates and Z-values for a right inferior parietal lobule activation), clearly coming from the healthy group. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state, and healthy-group whole-brain results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Note: sample size is small and only males were included, but these do not violate the review inclusion/exclusion criteria.

While the study is an fMRI investigation of social processing in healthy adults (viewing angry vs. neutral faces) and meets the sample and task criteria, it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group. The paper reports ROI percent signal-change results (FFA and amygdala) and multiple seed-based PPI connectivity analyses (seed-based functional connectivity), with cluster coordinates reported in supplements. The face localizer was used to define individual FFAs rather than presenting an unmasked, group-level whole-brain activation contrast (e.g., faces>baseline or angry>neutral) generalizable to the healthy adult population. Because the manuscript’s main reported voxelwise results are seed-based connectivity (PPI) and ROI analyses—and no univariate whole-brain healthy-group task activation map is provided—the study fails the “whole-brain evidence” inclusion criterion.

This fMRI study uses a social-related task (visual perception of biological motion — perception/understanding of others). The sample includes 15 healthy adult controls reported separately (age- and IQ-matched to OCD patients), satisfying the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked contrasts (biological motion vs scrambled) for the healthy/control group (tables and figures of group activation maps and second-level random-effects analyses are presented), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state methods, and healthy-group task effects are explicitly reported. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12, mean age 25.2) that explicitly probes social cognition (agency attribution/theory of mind using Heider–Simmel-style animations). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (high>low intentionality and low>high) analyzed with random-effects SPM2 and thresholded at p<0.001, with reported activated regions and figures. Results for the healthy adult group are presented directly and are generalizable (not limited to a clinical subgroup). The study is empirical, task-based, and not ROI-, connectivity-, or resting-state-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although the study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants performing a social task (facial emotion recognition) and reports whole-brain voxelwise results, the reported whole-brain maps are presented only as between-group contrasts (LDA > HDA and HDA > LDA). The paper does not provide an unmasked, within-group or overall healthy-group task activation map (e.g., Emo_Emo > Neu_Age for the healthy sample or each healthy subgroup alone as an unconditioned task effect) that would be generalizable to the healthy adult population. According to the review’s exclusion criteria, studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded. Other inclusion criteria (healthy adults, social task, age range) are met, but absence of a standalone healthy-group whole-brain task map prevents inclusion.

Although this is a task-based fMRI study of social processing that reports whole-brain, within-group activation maps for the typically developing (healthy) group (Direct > Averted gaze contrasts are provided in Table 2), the healthy/control sample includes adolescents (reported age range 16.1–42.4). The review requires a healthy adult group age 17–65 or a separately reported healthy adult subgroup. The paper does not present a separate analysis restricted to participants ≥17 years. Therefore the sample criterion is not met, so the study must be excluded despite meeting the other inclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI of empathy for pain, a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; mean age 33 ±9, within 17–65) with group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses and contrasts (e.g., Painful vs Nonpainful; Painful vs Baseline) reported for the control group. Whole-brain results are presented in tables of coordinates and figures, and regression analyses for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and provides univariate whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=30, ages ~26) examining perception and understanding of self and others (body perception, self–other distinction), which falls under the review’s social-related constructs. The authors report whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., own body > scrambled, same-sex other > scrambled, opposite-sex other > scrambled) with cluster-corrected voxelwise thresholds and report group comparisons and coordinate tables/figures. Results are reported separately for healthy male and female participants (healthy sample only). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, not non-empirical, participant ages within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (self- and mother-reflection vs celebrity) using healthy adult participants (Chinese college students, final N=34, ages ~19.5 within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (self- vs celebrity; mother- vs celebrity) and whole-brain regression/hierarchical analyses with coordinates and tables of activations (thresholds and correction procedures described), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample is healthy adults and results are reported for the healthy/control group. The study does not rely only on ROI, connectivity-only, or non-empirical methods. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using an interactive social decision-making task (modified prisoner’s dilemma) that probes social cognition/Theory of Mind. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=20, ages 23–45) reported separately from the clinical group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts for the healthy group (e.g., COMP>CONT, COOP>CONT, RAND>CONT and TASK>CONT), with results presented in tables/figures and cluster-level corrected maps. The reported analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches; whole-brain activation maps for the healthy/control group are explicitly described and used in conjunction analyses. Age range and reporting meet inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing (mothers viewing affective clips of their own vs unfamiliar children) and reports whole-brain, voxelwise task results, the sample consists exclusively of clinically depressed mothers (no healthy/control group). The review requires at least one group of healthy adults (age 17–65) with a reported whole-brain task activation map for the healthy group. This manuscript does not report data from a healthy adult group or healthy-subgroup contrasts; all reported whole-brain results are from the clinical sample. Therefore it fails the required sample criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of fearful vs. neutral body actions—social communication/perception of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=12, adult males within the 17–65 range) reported separately alongside an ASD group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts for the control group (e.g., Dynamic vs. Static; Fearful vs. Neutral), with tables of coordinates and statistical maps (see Tables 2–4 and Figures), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although the study uses fMRI with a naturalistic social stimulus and includes a healthy adult control group (NT; ages within 17–65), the full text does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. Reported whole-brain maps are either collapsed across ASD+NT or are between-group contrasts (NT > ASD). The paper provides ROI analyses, individual-subject peak extractions, and functional connectivity results, but no unmasked NT-alone whole-brain task effect (or coordinates/figure/table explicitly labeled as the healthy-group main effect) that is generalizable to healthy adults. Because the inclusion criterion requiring a whole-brain task-evoked map for the healthy/control group is not met, the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of pragmatic (social) language processing (integration of speaker characteristics and sentence content), clearly a social-related task (social communication, perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=24; ages 18–39). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts for the control group (within-group contrasts and whole-brain analyses with tables of significant clusters for speaker-incongruent > speaker-congruent and speaker-congruent > speaker-incongruent; Tables 4 and 5 and Figures), not limited to ROI-only results. Although a clinical ASD group is also included, whole-brain results for the healthy control group are reported separately and meet the inclusion requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age outside range, or absence of healthy-group whole-brain maps) are violated.

This study used resting-state fMRI and connectome-wide (MDMR) analyses to link individual network topology to emotional intelligence; it did not employ a social-related task or report any group-level, task-evoked whole-brain activation maps for healthy adults. Per inclusion criteria, studies must report task-based whole-brain (voxelwise) results from healthy adult participants. The manuscript reports only resting-state connectivity findings (and includes a trans-diagnostic sample), so it meets the exclusion criterion: studies reporting only resting-state analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=18 males, ages 18–24), using a task (listening to and rating musical excerpts) that produced task-evoked activations in brain regions linked to social cognition (DMN/ToM: arMFC, PCC/PC, temporal pole, TPJ/angular gyrus, hippocampus) and was interpreted by the authors as involving cognitive empathy and social-cognitive processes. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts (popular vs notes, artistic vs notes, and popular vs artistic) with tables/coordinates, cluster-level FDR correction and ROI follow-ups — not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants fall within the eligible adult age range. Although the task is aesthetic judgment rather than an explicit social-interaction paradigm, the authors explicitly link observed whole-brain activations to social-cognition/theory-of-mind processes, making the study relevant to social-related processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI during a social-related emotional face recognition task (social perception/understanding of others). (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=116 males, mean age 24.7, within 17–65). (3) Reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical results (e.g., Fear>Neutral contrasts with voxelwise FWE-corrected results, whole-brain regression analyses), not limited to ROI-only analyses. (4) Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not only ROI, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, or non-empirical). Therefore include.

Although the study used fMRI in healthy adults and included annotations for 'social communication' among many natural-scene categories, it did not employ an explicit social-related task or report a clear group-level univariate whole-brain task activation map for social processing in the healthy/control group. The primary analyses are voxelwise encoding models and cluster analyses of category tuning within scene-selective ROIs (and projection maps), rather than standard within-group task contrasts (e.g., social > non-social) or univariate statistical maps targeted to social constructs. Therefore it does not meet the requirement for a whole-brain, group-level, univariate task-evoked map of social-related processing and is ineligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI of facial emotion discrimination, a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). Participants include healthy adult controls (NC; ages 19–35) screened with a clinical interview. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task activation results and within-group contrasts for the control group (e.g., AH vs HH with FWE-corrected clusters reported), not only ROI or connectivity analyses. Methods and results present univariate, group-level whole-brain statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. Age range and reporting meet inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study uses task fMRI of social-emotional/simulation processes and includes a healthy adult control group (N=24, ages within 20–53), it does not report an univariate whole-brain, group-level task activation map that is clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group alone. Whole-brain results presented are for the combined HC+SZ sample (main effects across both groups) and ROI analyses are reported for individually-defined sensorimotor ROIs. Because the paper does not provide a healthy-group whole-brain task contrast (only combined-sample whole-brain maps and ROI results), it fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence from the healthy/control group and thus must be excluded under the review’s criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (male, age 19–60) using a deception task that probes social cognition/understanding of others (deception, theory-of-mind-related processes). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain task contrasts (lie vs truth), thresholded maps and coordinates (Table 2/3, figures), and discusses whole-brain findings; results are generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes appropriate whole-brain univariate activation maps for the healthy group. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (Multifaceted Empathy Test) probing cognitive and emotional empathy. It includes a healthy adult control group (female controls, ages in the reported range ~27–33). The paper reports univariate, whole-brain, task-evoked group-level activation results for the control group (see Tables 5 and 6 and accompanying text showing main effects of cognitive and emotional empathy in control subjects with MNI coordinates). Analyses used standard GLM-based whole-brain approaches (FSL) and report voxelwise activations generalizable to healthy adults. The study therefore meets the review’s inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult whole-brain results). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or missing healthy-group whole-brain maps) are violated.

This is an event-related fMRI study of evaluative judgments (self-referential/social-cognition task) that falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=7, mean age 26.4±4.6, within 17–65) reported separately from the patient group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate activation results for the control group (one-sample t-test; threshold z>3.10) with coordinates and cluster information (Table 3 and figures), satisfying the requirement for a whole-brain task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults. It is empirical original fMRI work (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study used task-based fMRI during a social-related imitate/observe facial-emotion task (social processes domain). The sample includes healthy adult participants (controls age 18–55) reported separately within the study (discovery and independent replication samples include healthy control groups). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (imitate > observe) analyzed with voxelwise approaches and threshold-free cluster enhancement, including group analyses run separately by site and diagnostic group (supplementary figures/tables show group maps), providing whole-brain, generalizable healthy-group activation results. The study is empirical, within the target age range, not ROI- or connectivity-only, and reports appropriate whole-brain task activation maps for controls, so it meets all inclusion criteria.

Study includes a healthy adult control group (n=22 behavioral; n=21 fMRI; ages 20–46), uses task-based fMRI during a social-related task (emotional prosody processing — perception/understanding of others), and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation results for controls (e.g., emotional vs neutral prosody contrasts, conjunction maps, FWE cluster-corrected whole-brain results). Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper also reports voxelwise effective connectivity (PPI) but importantly provides whole-brain task activation maps for the control group, not limited to ROI-only analyses. Thus all inclusion criteria are met.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social cognition (approachability and intelligence judgements from faces) in healthy adults (47 controls, ages ~32, within 17–65). Group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts for the healthy/control groups are reported (social vs gender contrasts; SPM2 analyses, voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level correction; coordinates and figures provided). Although a clinical ASD group is also included, healthy-group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI of social processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level activation maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

The study uses task fMRI with healthy adult controls (n=14) and a social-perception task, but the paper’s whole-brain reported results focus on between-group contrasts (HC vs SZ). There is no unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) healthy-control task activation map (e.g., HC social>nonsocial or other within-group whole-brain contrast) clearly reported for the healthy group; within-group follow-up statistics are derived from ROIs based on between-group clusters rather than an independent whole-brain healthy-group map. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (n=10) and reports group-level whole-brain univariate activation maps for the control group, the experimental task is a continuous performance task with monetary reward (reward processing/attention). The task does not engage social-related processing (e.g., social communication, perception/understanding of self/others, affiliation/attachment) nor use social stimuli or social cognitive paradigms. Thus it fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI task tapping social-related processing. No ROI-only or connectivity-only issues apply; exclusion is solely because the task is not social in nature.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (emotion understanding/attribution) in healthy adults (N=22, ages 19–32). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (How>Why, Why>How) with tables of MNI coordinates and FDR-corrected results, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task is social (perception and understanding of others). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, includes healthy adult group results, not only connectivity or between-group contrasts). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI study using a social-affective task (film clips of people in distress) in a healthy adult sample (n=15, ages 45–62). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Watch-Negative > Watch-Neutral; Compassion > Watch-Negative; Reappraisal > Watch-Negative) with cluster-level FWE correction, presented in tables/figures and described in text. Not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain results are clearly reported. Although participants are expert meditators (a specialized healthy subgroup), they are within the eligible age range and reported separately. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (30 native Japanese speakers) that manipulated communicative vs descriptive speech in L1 and L2 — a social-communication task relevant to the review’s scope (Social Communication). The abstract reports group-level task-evoked activation results (e.g., left posterior supramarginal gyrus, left MTG, OFC/insula), consistent with univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants are described as healthy adult native speakers; although exact ages are not provided in the abstract, the sample is presented as adult language learners and thus falls within the review’s target population. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only groups, non-empirical) appear to be violated. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI evidence of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: the study used task-based fMRI of a social-related process (facial emotion processing). It includes a healthy adult control group (N=31; age range reported 19.68–36.39, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses for the healthy/control group (one-sample and paired t-tests; results reported in tables and text, e.g., Table 3 and supplemental within-group t-tests) with FWE-corrected whole-brain thresholds. It is empirical and provides whole-brain task activation maps/coordinate results for the healthy group, so it is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

The sample comprises adolescents (depressed and healthy adolescents), not adults. The review requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65; no healthy adult subgroup is analyzed or reported separately. Although the study uses fMRI during a social task (Cyberball) and reports whole-brain task contrasts, it fails the age/sample inclusion criterion, so it must be excluded.

Although the study includes an fMRI subsample and a social-phobia-related word task, the fMRI sample consists only of 25 female patients with SAD and the reported fMRI results concern patients (correlations of methylation with amygdala response). The paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for a healthy/control group (healthy participants are present in other parts of the study but not in the fMRI analyses as presented).
