Analyses appear focused on an amygdala ROI and on patient-only effects; no unmasked whole-brain healthy-group activation map or coordinates for the healthy group are provided. Therefore the study fails the inclusion criterion requiring a whole-brain healthy-group task activation map and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (fearful faces with gaze direction) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=22, mean age 23.7±5.9) reported separately from the ASD group. The paper presents whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked group analyses for the control group (within-group contrasts such as AVERTED>DIRECT and AVERTED>FIXATION) with thresholding, TFCE/FWE correction, and reported activation maps/tables. The task is clearly social (perception/understanding of others). Thus all inclusion criteria are met (fMRI social task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain univariate group-level results generalizable to healthy adults). No exclusion criteria apply.

This paper reports event-related fMRI of implicit facial emotion processing (a clearly social task) including a separate healthy adult control group (n=9, mean age ~27, within 17–65). The manuscript provides group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts for the control group (face vs fixation; emotion intensity trends; tables of coordinates and figures), and reports activations generalizable to healthy adults. It therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample reported separately, whole-brain univariate group maps presented). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=35, ages 22.6–55.4) that investigates emotion regulation during participant-generated autobiographical social situations (social embarrassment/shame) — a social-related task involving perception/understanding of self. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (react vs neutral; reappraisal vs react; acceptance vs react; direct contrasts) with cluster-corrected voxelwise results, tables and figures, and an a priori amygdala ROI supplement. All inclusion criteria are met (social task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level maps reported). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

Meets all inclusion criteria. The study uses task-based fMRI probing a social cognition construct (third-party punishment/mentalizing and social decision-making). Sample: 26 healthy adult participants (mean age 26), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (GLM contrast Decision Phase: Experimental > Control) with whole-brain FDR-corrected maps (q(FDR)<0.05) and tables/coordinates, plus a parametric modulation cluster-level correction—thus providing whole-brain voxelwise activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Although the paper also reports effective connectivity (GCA), it additionally provides the required univariate whole-brain healthy-group task effects. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult group reported). Therefore include.

This study reports task-based fMRI in a sample of healthy adults (22 participants aged ~23), using a social attention paradigm (gaze vs arrow cueing) that probes social perception/communication processes. The paper presents group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses (whole-brain FWE-corrected thresholds and reported clusters; peak coordinates/tables and figures), and additionally reports ROI/SVC results. All inclusion criteria are satisfied: (1) fMRI during a social-related task, (2) healthy adult sample within 17–65, (3) group-level whole-brain task-evoked univariate maps are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and empirical data are provided). Therefore the study should be included.

This study used task-based fMRI including an altruism paradigm (choices affecting self and an anonymous partner), which directly probes social cognition (perception/understanding of others and social decision-making). Participants were healthy adults (N=55 for altruism; subset N=37 for food), ages within 17–65. The paper reports whole-brain voxelwise GLMs (trial-wise choice regressors) and refers to conventional univariate analyses (Appendix 1 – Univariate Analysis of fMRI Data), and presents group-level voxelwise results and cluster coordinates (conjunctions, MNI coordinates) for neural effects; these meet the requirement for group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps (reported in main text and supplementary material). The study does not restrict results to ROIs only, nor is it solely connectivity or resting-state. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an original fMRI study with healthy adult participants (final N=23, mean age 26.4, right-handed, within 17–65). The task probes social perception (animacy, action observation, mentalizing) during event-related fMRI. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (main effects of agent form and belief manipulation, and interactions) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level corrections; peak coordinates and cluster tables are provided. Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity only. Healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (direct vs. averted gaze; social cognition, perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (n=30; ages 19–41). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked analyses (main effects and contrasts of congruency and gaze) using voxelwise statistics with cluster-forming and FWE correction and provides coordinates/tables and figures of activation maps; thus whole-brain evidence is available. Although the study also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it additionally reports univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy/control group. Participants are within the required age range and results for the healthy sample are reported. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, empirical original fMRI data). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (Naïve n=11, Trained n=10, Expert n=5) that investigates observational understanding/ social cognition (perception and understanding of others, mentalizing) during toolmaking demonstrations. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Toolmaking vs Control; Acheulean vs Oldowan) with voxelwise statistical maps and tables of coordinates (FDR-corrected results, extent thresholds). Results for the healthy groups are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults (no clinical groups). The study uses task-based fMRI (not only ROI, connectivity, or resting-state), and provides whole-brain activation maps and coordinate tables. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: the study uses task-based fMRI during a social interaction paradigm (cyberball) directly probing social exclusion/inclusion; includes a healthy adult control group (n=20, ages within adult range) with results reported separately; reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (main effect of condition, interaction effects, and a two-sample t-test for group effects) and refers to t-contrasts in the Supplementary Data, and the text describes within-group post-hoc activations for the healthy control group. The task and reported whole-brain results are relevant to social-related processing (affiliation/mentalizing). No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are reported/described). Therefore the paper is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social-approval paradigm (self vs other; high/low social reward) — a clearly social-related task (self-processing/social reward). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; age range 20–51) reported separately from the clinical (schizophrenia) group. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise group-level task activation maps and tables of coordinates for the healthy control group (one-sample t-tests and contrasts shown in Table 3 and figures), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain univariate task-evoked results generalizable to healthy adults. Although a clinical group is also included, control-group results are presented independently. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This fMRI study includes a healthy adult control group (n=8, male, mean age ~23) and uses a social-communication relevant task (listening to prosodically-rich connected speech; assesses social/pragmatic prosody). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses for the control group (one-sample t-tests showing activations and deactivations; voxelwise thresholds reported, FDR cluster correction), not only ROI or connectivity results. Although sample size is small, control-group whole-brain maps are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-based fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (theory of mind / intentions) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=12, mean age 24.8) alongside a patient group. The paper reports second-level, group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (within-group contrasts for the control group versus the physical-causality control condition), with tables of coordinates and figures illustrating activations in canonical ToM regions. Analyses are generalizable (random-effects second-level SPM ANOVA). The study is empirical, within the 17–65 age range, and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are met, so it qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis of whole-brain task-evoked social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of communicative (social) speech production in healthy adults (n=27 analyzed; ages 19–31), addressing social communication and understanding others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and interaction effects (e.g., COM vs DES, L2 vs L1, interaction L2COM-L2DES vs L1COM-L1DES) with peak coordinates and cluster statistics in multiple tables/figures (Tables 1–5, Figures 2–6). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and reports healthy control group results generalizable to adults within the 17–65 range. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked social processing fMRI in healthy adults and should be included.

This is an fMRI study using an empathy-for-pain social task (empathic responses to a partner’s pain), which falls under social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The sample includes a healthy control group of adults (n=18, age range 22–63) reported separately from the autism group. The paper reports whole-brain task analyses and provides group-level voxelwise results/coordinates (e.g., left anterior insula coordinates and whole-brain contrasts reported; Supplementary Table 1 and main-text coordinates; group-level HighPain>LowPain contrasts and control-group activations are described). Although ROI analyses are used, whole-brain univariate results for healthy participants are presented. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of visual sensitivity to social configurations (face-to-face vs back-to-back body dyads), which squarely addresses social perception/understanding of others. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=20 in fMRI; age mean ~24), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., dyads > single-bodies; facing > nonfacing dyads) with explicit thresholds and cluster correction, and includes whole-brain tables/figures (Table 1, Fig. 2a). The study therefore provides task-evoked, whole-brain healthy-group activation maps (not ROI-only or connectivity-only) and meets all inclusion criteria.

Although this study uses task fMRI and includes a healthy neurotypical (NT) control group and social processing tasks (eye gaze, face processing), the full text provided emphasizes effective connectivity / causal network analyses and does not present or describe any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation maps or tables of coordinates for the healthy/control group. The methods and results focus on network/effective connectivity comparisons (e.g., causal search procedures) rather than reporting unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task activation effects. Per the review’s inclusion/exclusion rules, studies that report only effective connectivity without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task map must be excluded.

Although the study uses fMRI of a social-communication task (audiovisual speech) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=15, age in range), the paper does not present a standalone, univariate whole-brain task activation map or contrast reported specifically for the healthy/control group. Reported whole-brain results are (1) a main congruency effect across the combined sample and (2) group × congruency interaction maps and extracted beta weights for each group. No unmasked, group-level healthy-control task activation map (voxelwise map or coordinates explicitly labeled as the healthy-group within-group contrast) is provided. This fails the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task evidence, and meets the exclusion criterion for studies that report only between-group contrasts/interactions without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task effect.

This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants imagined encountering neutral faces in goal-relevant vs. goal-irrelevant social situations (social cognition/perception of others). Sample: healthy adults (N=17; ages 20–36) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (second-level random-effects ANOVAs; voxelwise thresholds and cluster correction; tables/figures of coordinates and activation maps), not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state results. Results for healthy participants are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

While the study uses task-based fMRI of social cognition and includes a healthy adult control group (n=20, ages 24–56), the paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. The reported analyses focus on diagnosis-by-task effects and between-group (patient vs control) contrasts and a conjunction analysis of areas where diagnosis influenced responses. There are no clearly identified, generalizable whole-brain healthy-group (control-only) task-evoked statistical maps presented in tables/figures/text (only group-difference/conjunction results are shown). Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group univariate results and must be excluded.

The study used fMRI while subjects viewed action sequences, a social perception task relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others.’ The full-text reports group-level neural adaptation effects in brain regions (pSTS, MT/MST, EBA) that distinguish actions, indicating univariate task-evoked activation results generalizable to healthy adult participants. No indication that the sample is clinical or outside the 17–65 range; the paper is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults. There is no evidence that results are ROI-only, connectivity-only, or limited to between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses fMRI during social-cognitive tasks (action understanding/Theory of Mind) and includes a healthy adult control group, the paper reports primarily between-group contrasts (ALS > HC and HC > ALS). The full text does not provide an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map or within-group (healthy-control) task effect clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (only HC>ALS between-group results are described). Per the review’s inclusion criteria, a separate whole-brain healthy-group task activation map is required. Because that criterion is not met, the study must be excluded.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (male, 18–35) and uses task-based fMRI of a social cognition task (trustworthiness judgments), the reported analyses are ROI-based percent signal change and group-level ROI statistics. The full text does not present any univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task activation maps or tables of coordinates clearly identified for the healthy/control group. Because the meta-analysis requires at least one healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map and this paper reports only ROI analyses, it fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (fMRI subgroup N=11, ages 21–29). The task examines perception/understanding of others’ actions (auditory mirror system; semantic priming of action meaning), which falls under social-related constructs (Perception and Understanding of Others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise analyses using SPM5 with random-effects statistics, cluster correction, and provides tables of coordinates and figures of activation maps (group-level univariate contrasts such as action-related vs non-action-related sounds and prime congruency effects). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and the healthy-control group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI of self- and other-reflection (social cognition: perception/understanding of self and others) including a healthy control group (n=33, ages 18–65). It provides group-level, whole-brain univariate results for the control group (Self>Facts, Other>Facts, Other>Self contrasts), with cluster-corrected voxelwise statistics and coordinates (figures and Supplementary Tables). Although the paper also includes a schizophrenia patient group, healthy-group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The analyses are not ROI-only and are task-evoked (not resting-state or connectivity-only). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study investigating reactive social aggression using a modified Taylor Aggression Paradigm in healthy adults (N=15 included; mean age 22.9). It reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses for decision and outcome phases with coordinates and tables (threshold p<0.001, cluster ≥20 voxels), and figures illustrating activations (insula, ACC, striatum, etc.). Results for the healthy control sample are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only restrictions apply. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study with a healthy adult sample (n=45, age 18–34). The affective creativity task (RGT) requires participants to imagine anger-eliciting situations caused by another person and to generate reappraisals, i.e., it explicitly engages social processing (perception/understanding of others, theory-of-mind/empathy aspects). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (conjunction and task contrasts RGT>AUT and AUT>RGT) with tables of MNI coordinates and FWE-corrected thresholds, meeting the whole-brain evidence criterion. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable within the adult range. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

Although the study uses simultaneous fMRI-PET in healthy adult mothers and probes social/affiliative processing (maternal bonding), the provided full text does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy adult group. The reported results focus on PET dopamine responses and intrinsic/network connectivity (seed/network analyses) rather than an unmasked whole-brain task activation map or coordinate table for a healthy-group task effect. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one healthy-group whole-brain task activation map, this paper does not meet all inclusion requirements and should be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related — self-perception/self-processing (participants rated whether they would like to smell like presented odours), a construct listed in the review (Perception and Understanding of Self). (2) Sample: healthy adult participants (ages 18–35), group-level results reported separately for healthy participants. (3) Whole-brain evidence: authors state that whole-brain analysis and second-level group contrasts were performed and report group-level voxelwise contrasts with MNI coordinates and statistical thresholds (e.g., ‘self’-peptide vs solvent; coordinates and p-values provided). Results are reported for group-level univariate task-evoked contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. (4) Not excluded by ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical criteria. Therefore include.

The paper reports a mega-analysis of fMRI studies using representational similarity and multivariate analyses of how mental states are neurally represented. However, the full text/abstract does not clearly report at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., main effect or within-group contrast) from a healthy adult sample. The methods emphasize RSA/neural pattern analyses rather than conventional univariate task activation maps, and no explicit univariate whole-brain healthy-group task effect is described in the provided content. Because the inclusion criteria require clear reporting of group-level univariate whole-brain results, this study does not meet that criterion based on the available information.

The study is an fMRI experiment of social perception (voice-based identity and emotion recognition), which directly addresses ‘perception and understanding of others’ — a social-related construct. Participants include healthy adult sighted controls (N=15, mean age ~32) reported separately alongside congenitally blind subjects. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM) with main effects and interactions, accompanied by figures and tables of cluster coordinates (e.g., main effects of Stimulus-Type, Group × Stimulus-Type interaction; Tables 2–5 and whole-brain maps). Analyses are not ROI-only (although ROIs/localisers are used supplemental to whole-brain results). Thus it meets inclusion criteria: fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and reported group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based fMRI during a social-related task (trust game / social cognition with Theory-of-Mind focus). (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=40 behavioral; n=34 fMRI), ages 19.5–32.7. (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (whole-brain contrasts, coordinates, cluster-level FWE and TFCE corrections) clearly from the healthy/control group. (4) Not limited to ROI/connectivity-only or to between-group contrasts; whole-brain healthy-group effects are presented and described. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is a task-based fMRI study using social scenarios (risky vs neutral decisions) examining emotional reactions to outcomes — a social-related task (perception/understanding of self/others). The sample includes a healthy young adult group (30 young adults) within the 17–65 range, and results are reported separately for age groups (effects described “for both age groups” and young-adult > adolescent contrasts). The abstract reports voxelwise regional activations across distributed brain regions (OFC, MTG, PCC, precuneus, insula, IFG, pre-SMA, caudate, STS), indicating whole-brain univariate task-evoked findings rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated (not resting-state, not ROI-only, includes healthy adult subgroup with whole-brain effects). Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social task (Trust Game) with healthy adult participants (ages 19–30) and reports voxelwise whole-brain statistics, the published results focus on between-group contrasts (high-Mach vs low-Mach) and activations reported as high-Mach > low-Mach. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map that is clearly identified as a general healthy/control group effect (or a full within-group GAME>CONTROL map for the overall healthy sample). Participants are an extreme-score, narrowly defined trait sub-sample (high vs low Machiavellianism). Because the paper appears to report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect generalizable to healthy adults, it fails the criterion requiring a group-level univariate whole-brain healthy control/task map. Therefore it should be excluded.

This study uses task-based fMRI of a social cognition paradigm (Theory of Mind/visual jokes) relevant to perception/understanding of others. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; ages ≈29) reported separately. The paper presents whole-brain, voxelwise, group-level task contrasts (ToM vs Physical) with random-effects analyses, cluster-corrected results and coordinate tables for the control group (within-group activations reported in Table 3 and figures). Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity, and healthy-group whole-brain activation maps are clearly described, meeting all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (learning others’ inter-temporal preferences and social influence on self-preferences) in healthy adult participants (fMRI sample n=29, mean age 25.6, 14 females; analyses exclude two, leaving healthy adults). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (repetition suppression and surprise/prediction-error contrasts) with cluster-level FWE correction and voxel coordinates, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task explicitly probes perception/understanding of others and social learning, matching the review constructs. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 17–65, empirical fMRI data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=14 males, mean age 25) that investigates observation and motor imagery of meaningful face and upper-limb movements, including socially communicative gestures. The task is social-related (social communication/gesture perception and self-related motor imagery). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (conjunctions, main effects, contrasts) with family-wise error corrected thresholds and tables of MNI coordinates and figures. It is task-based (not only ROI, connectivity, or resting-state) and reports healthy-group results directly. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=18, right-handed, mean ages ~25–26 within 17–65). The study investigates social-communication relevant processes (vitality forms of speech and actions). Authors report group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts and conjunctions (e.g., Vitality vs Control; coordinates and cluster statistics are provided with PFWE thresholds) and present whole-brain tables/figures and PPI results. Although they also present ROI analyses, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked maps for the healthy/control group are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a non-empirical paper, and sample is within age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social-related task (explicit and implicit processing of emotional facial expressions). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=9, mean age 27±7) within the 17–65 range. Analyses are whole-brain, voxelwise (FPQ-based BOLD mapping) with group-level statistical results reported (Table 2) and coordinates provided for main effects and diagnosis×task interactions. The text explicitly describes activations in the control group (e.g., left cerebellum and left amygdalohippocampal region activated in controls but not in autistic subjects), indicating healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain results are available. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or resting-state, and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=10, ages 20–29) using a task involving perception of human biological motion (listening to walking human footsteps), which maps onto social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (contrast ‘footstep minus rest’) with tables of cluster coordinates and t-values (random-effects analysis), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for healthy adults are reported separately and are generalizable to the healthy adult population. The study is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses; although connectivity is discussed, whole-brain activation maps are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task of social appraisal (preference judgments of faces vs gender), which is a social-related construct (perception/understanding of others). The study includes a healthy adult group (n=21, mean age ~39.8, within 17–65) and reports results for that healthy group separately. The paper provides whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task activation results for the healthy controls (PREF > GENDER contrasts by valence presented in Figures and Tables 2–4 with MNI coordinates and cluster statistics), satisfying the requirement for group-level whole-brain maps generalizable to healthy adults. The article also reports between-group contrasts and connectivity analyses, but it is not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=22, mean age 24.8) investigating emotional speech prosody (social communication). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (cluster-corrected emotional > neutral prosody; Right STG cluster reported in Table 2 and whole-brain figures), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task is social-related (perception of others’ emotional prosody). Results for the healthy adult group are reported directly (not limited to a clinical subgroup). The study is empirical and not exclusively ROI- or connectivity-based. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This fMRI study tests peer (social) influence during task performance (peer observation manipulation during the Stoplight risky-driving task and Go/No-Go), which is a social-related process (social influence/understanding of others). Sample consists of healthy young adults (ages 21–24). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation results using standard subtraction contrasts (e.g., No-Go > Go; Risk > Safe) and provides thresholded and unthresholded maps in NeuroVault, fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the paper also presents seed-based connectivity analyses, it does not rely solely on ROI/connectivity reports — whole-brain activation maps for the healthy adult sample are explicitly reported. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants are within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although this is an fMRI task probing social-related processing (personal familiarity) and reports whole-brain, within-group voxelwise results for the healthy control group, the control sample is described as 'healthy elderly' and no ages or a 17–65 adult subgroup are provided. The meta-analysis requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65 (or a separately reported subgroup in that range). Because the healthy participants are characterized as elderly and no evidence is given that they fall within the 17–65 age range, the study does not meet the sample-age inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This fMRI study examines social cognition using the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Task (mental state recognition) and a matched age-judgement comparison. The sample includes 25 healthy adult controls (reported separately, age range 18–59) alongside Tourette syndrome patients. Whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses were performed and reported (methods: FSL, voxelwise thresholding, FWE correction) with healthy-control activation results described (Supplementary Table S2) and discussed in the text. The task probes social/other perception and mentalizing (relevant constructs). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adult group within 17–65, and reports whole-brain healthy-group task effects). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (perception/understanding of others via biological motion and mentalizing) in healthy adult participants (n=12, mean age 27.3). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (main effect of stimulus presentation, factorial ANOVA, ANCOVAs correlating behavioural measures with whole-brain contrasts) with tables of coordinates and cluster statistics (FDR-corrected). It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based fMRI of a social-related paradigm (anticipation of touching an animate vs. inanimate target). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=32, ages 21–33; task data in a subgroup of 21 but healthy adults reported separately). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise univariate analyses (paired-sample t-test for animate vs. inanimate anticipation, whole-brain one-sample tests with narcissism covariates) with FDR-corrected statistical maps and reported coordinates. Results are generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=27, mean age 27) that investigated processing of others’ facial expressions (social perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (e.g., canonical disgust vs neutral; canonical disgust vs distaste; distaste vs neutral) with cluster coordinates and FDR-corrected results (see Table 2 and figures). Although ROI analyses were used a priori for the insula, whole-brain random-effects results are clearly reported. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are presented. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, or outside age range) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study in healthy adult participants (ages ~21–33), examining processing of actions with explicit ‘why’ (mentalizing/abstract/social) vs ‘how’ (concrete) judgments. The task probes social-cognitive/understanding-of-others constructs (mentalizing/default-mode network). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses and conjunction contrasts with coordinates and cluster-corrected maps, and presents tables/figures of whole-brain results for the healthy control sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, not only between-group contrasts). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study uses task-based fMRI probing social-emotional face processing (fearful vs scrambled/calm faces), which is a social-related task. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=13; age range 26–55, mean ~39.8) reported separately from the clinical premutation group. The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain task activation results for the control group (within-group contrasts and tables of peak coordinates, figures showing bilateral amygdala and other activations), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the study also includes a clinical premutation group, results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or absent healthy-group whole-brain map) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of action/interaction observation (social perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (N=29, ages 18–28). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Observation > Neutral; 2H DIFF > 2H SAME; Squeeze > No Squeeze) with FWE-corrected results, peak coordinates, figures, and tables—meeting the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy/control group. The task is an explicit social-related action observation paradigm (not resting-state or connectivity-only), and results for the healthy sample are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not connectivity-only; participants within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adults (N=20, ages 18–29). The task is explicitly social (impression formation/decisions about target persons across situational contexts). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task analyses (multilevel whole-brain MLM and cluster-wise results with MNI coordinates and thresholding), along with ROI follow-ups — satisfying the requirement for univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps from the healthy group. Participants are within the eligible adult age range and results are reported for the healthy sample. The study does not fall under any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a between-group-only contrast, and is original empirical data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of a social-cognitive (visual perspective-taking) paradigm and includes a healthy adult control group with reported activation patterns, the analyses were explicitly restricted to an a priori combined region-of-interest mask rather than an unmasked whole-brain voxelwise analysis. The paper reports ROI-constrained activation and seed-based ROI connectivity results; it does not present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy/control group. Therefore it fails the review’s required ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (persuasion/expert influence) in healthy adult participants (young right-handed females, mean age 21.8). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation analyses (SME/SAE and expertise contrasts) with tables of coordinates and statistical maps; although ROIs/SVC were used for some hypotheses, whole-brain results are reported and discussed. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are clearly presented. The study is not connectivity-only, not a review, and includes original fMRI data generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (facial emotion recognition). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (14 males, mean age 23.6) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked analyses (exploratory whole-brain results and tables of activated clusters) for the NT control group (e.g., inferior frontal gyrus and fusiform gyrus clusters), not only ROI analyses. The healthy-group maps and coordinates are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults, satisfying all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of others’ emotional facial and prosodic cues — social communication/perception). Sample includes healthy adults (Study 1: N=10, ages 18–33; Study 2: N=5, ages 18–23) within the 17–65 range, reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts and maps (multiple whole-brain analyses and conjunctions are described; Tables 3–4 and figures show voxelwise peaks and cluster coordinates with thresholds p<.001/.0001 and statements like “Whole-brain analysis on group averaged maps”), not only ROI or connectivity results. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=7, ages 20–35). Task involved reading sentences that include social content (people, social interactions, social norms); factor analysis identifies a clear ‘people/social interactions’ dimension linked to specific brain regions. Whole-brain fMRI data were collected and group-level analyses/factor-derived voxel clusters and associated brain locations are reported (group-level results and voxel clusters across cortex; Supporting Information reported). The study reports task-evoked activation patterns generalizable to healthy adults and not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (observation of mouth actions/oral communicative actions) in healthy adults. Sample: 60 right-handed healthy participants (ages 18–60) meeting the age criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (within-group and between-group ANOVAs, paired t-tests) with results shown in tables of coordinates and FWE-corrected voxelwise thresholds. Whole-brain activations (e.g., IFG, MTG, amygdala, cerebellum) are reported clearly for the healthy groups. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of naturalistic social cognition (mentalising/ToM) using a task with dynamic film stimuli. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=22, ages 19–46) with results reported separately. The paper reports within-group whole-brain univariate task contrasts (ToM > physical inference) for the control group, with cluster-corrected whole-brain activations presented in figures and Table 3. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level task-evoked maps) and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of face processing (social perception/Perception and Understanding of Others), using a face>object/texture localizer and passive viewing blocks. It includes a healthy adult sample (51 adults, ages 18–42) reported separately from children. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (face>object, face>texture) using mixed-effects FLAME analyses with cluster correction and presents whole-brain statistical maps and ROI definitions derived from those maps. The study is task-evoked, univariate, and provides healthy-group whole-brain activation results generalizable to adults, meeting all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=16, ages ~21), using task-based paradigms assessing judgments of pride and joy (social/self-conscious and basic positive emotions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (pride vs neutral, joy vs neutral, pride vs joy) with voxelwise statistical maps reported as peak coordinates, tables, and figures, and regression analyses linking ratings to activations. The task addresses social-related processing (perception/understanding of self and others/toM). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, not only between-group contrasts, participants are within 17–65). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=12, mean age 21) that explicitly investigates social cognition (monitoring/mentalizing about others' decisions). The authors report group-level, voxelwise second-level analyses (random-effects ANOVA, F-contrasts) and present SPM maps and peak coordinates for activations in the ACC (with small-volume correction applied to an anatomically defined ACC mask). Results are task-evoked, univariate, and reported for the healthy participant group. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range). Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

Study is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18, final N=17; ages 19–36). Task probes face perception/recognition (socially relevant: perception/understanding of others). Authors report group-level, whole-brain random-effects contrasts (differential activations for false recognition vs. hits/correct rejections) with cluster correction and Talairach coordinates; results presented as whole-brain maps/coordinates (not ROI-only). Age range and healthy-group reporting meet inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria (not connectivity-only, not clinical-only). Therefore it qualifies for inclusion.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) that includes a healthy adult control group (age-matched; n=28). The task probes mental state/affective theory-of-mind (social perception). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise group-level results and coordinates (Tables 2 and 3; figures and supporting information) including contrasts and comparisons involving the healthy control group and control subgroup effects. Although clinical HD groups are the primary focus, healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked results and comparisons are clearly reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults, satisfying inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study of social perception (masked fearful vs happy eye whites) in healthy adult participants (initial N=50; analyzed N=43; ages ~24). The task probes social-related processing (perception of others’ emotional eye cues) and includes a standard group-level random-effects analysis. Although ROI/SVC analyses in the amygdala are reported, the paper also reports exploratory whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Fearful>Happy) with reported clusters (pulvinar, ACC, orbitofrontal cortex) and references to Supplementary Tables of whole-brain results. Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in a sample of healthy adult participants using a task probing neutral face processing, emotion recognition, and affective theory-of-mind (social-related constructs). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task effects (one-sample t-tests and whole-brain contrasts) with a stated whole-brain significance threshold (p<0.05 FWE, k=10) and presents whole-brain results (figures and Supplementary Table). Although ROI and connectivity analyses are also reported, whole-brain, healthy-group task activation maps are clearly provided. Participants are healthy adults and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of face perception that explicitly manipulates changeable social aspects (gaze, expression, viewpoint)—tasks directly related to Social Communication/Perception of Others. Participants are healthy adult subjects (n=8) and results are reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate analyses (FEAT Z-statistic images, thresholded maps, and Talairach coordinates in Table 1) for contrasts such as faces > objects and adaptation effects, providing whole-brain activation information (figures and coordinate tables). The study is empirical, not connectivity-only, and includes whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Study uses task-based fMRI during a social-related task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, affective Theory of Mind). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=18; ages within 17–65) with results analyzed separately. The methods describe group-level, voxelwise whole-brain one-sample t tests for each of the five groups and second-level whole-brain between-group ANOVAs; reported whole-brain activation results and coordinates (cluster- and FWE-corrected) are provided in the paper (figures/tables and ROI follow-ups). The paper is empirical and not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for providing a healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map suitable for the meta-analysis.

This study includes a healthy adult control group (n=18; mean age ~28.6) and uses task-based fMRI to probe processing of emotion words — a social/emotion-related construct relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Self/Other’. The paper reports voxelwise, whole-brain, task-evoked statistical results: FWE-corrected whole-brain contrasts (controls > ASC) identifying clusters (motor, insula, basal ganglia) with coordinates, and within-group analyses in the control sample showing emotion-word-specific activations (reported with statistics). These results are presented at the group level and are generalizable to healthy adults. Although several contrasts are reported as between-group (controls>ASC), the manuscript also provides control-related group effects and coordinates and thus supplies whole-brain univariate evidence from the healthy/control group. Therefore the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social-interactive 'virtual handshake' task that manipulates social acceptance vs. rejection (social-related processing). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=16; mean age ~27) reported separately from the schizophrenia group. The paper reports group-level, within-group whole-brain univariate contrasts for the healthy/control group (refusal > acceptance), with reported regions (right pSTS, right thalamus) and cluster/statistical thresholds; results are described in text/tables/figures and are generalizable to healthy adults. Although a clinical group is present, healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly provided. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes appropriate age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult participants (N=30, mean age 21.2). The task probes social cooperation/defection (affiliation/social decision-making), satisfying the social-related task requirement. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (random-effects and fixed-effects), thresholded maps and coordinate tables for within-group contrasts (e.g., choice C vs D; CC, CD, DC, DD vs others), and figures showing activations (including whole-brain voxelwise results and tables). Results are reported for the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range age) are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This fMRI study used a social-related face-processing task (Thatcher Illusion) probing social/emotional processing. It reports data from a healthy adult control group (NT; n=18, mean age ~25.8, within the 17–65 range) separately from the ASD group. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (upright vs. inverted) for the control group, including mixed-effects GLM (FLAME) results and thresholding (cluster Z>2.3, corrected p=0.05) and displays whole-brain activation maps and descriptions. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (social task, healthy adult sample reported separately, and whole-brain task-evoked group results). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults).

This is an fMRI study of social processing (gaze perception/communicative intent; theory-of-mind network), meeting the social-related task requirement. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (male adults, reported separately from the ASC group). The paper reports group-level, univariate within-group contrasts for controls (e.g., controls: direct gaze > averted gaze) with coordinates and figures, and describes whole-brain contrasts (faces vs. null) that were FWE-corrected at the whole-brain level used to define control networks. Results for the healthy/control group are presented separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, task-based fMRI (not solely connectivity/ROI-only), so it satisfies all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

While the study uses task-based fMRI of social (Theory of Mind) processing and includes a healthy adult control group, it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. The paper’s primary analyses use group ICA (multivariate/task-related functional connectivity) with component maps derived from the combined sample (n=36) and between-group comparisons (ASD vs control). No unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect (e.g., GLM contrast or control-only group map/coordinates) is provided that meets the meta-analysis requirement. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring a healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical map and falls under the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only connectivity/ICA results without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain activation map.

This study uses fMRI during a social-related task (the Cyberball social exclusion paradigm). It includes a healthy adult control group (HC; n=28) with results reported separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate effects for the healthy controls (main effect of condition in HC: left anterior insula/inferior frontal gyrus) thresholded at voxelwise FWE-corrected p<0.05 with k≥10 voxels, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the sample is female-only, participants are healthy adults and the healthy-group whole-brain task activation is clearly presented, so the study meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social attribution (inferring situational causes of avatars’ emotional behaviors) that included a healthy adult control group (n=16). The authors performed whole-brain, voxelwise GLM analyses and report cluster coordinates and statistics (Table 1) and mean % signal changes for the control group, indicating healthy-group task-evoked univariate effects (e.g., significant positive % signal changes in IFG, VPMC, etc.). The task is a social-related process (attribution of others’ emotions) and results for the healthy/control group are presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state only, or absence of healthy-group whole-brain task effect) apply. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the review.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adult samples (three studies; mean ages ~20) involving social-related tasks (persuasion/mentalizing, perception and understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (persuasive > unpersuasive) with thresholding and coordinate tables/figures (e.g., p < .001 uncorrected; Tables/Figures reporting MNI coordinates), which are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control groups. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (male college students, ages ~20–23) using a task that probes social-related processing (fan identity, self-referential processing, perspective taking/mentalizing about players and rival fans). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM; tables and figures list whole-brain activation for contrasts such as emotional intensity and valence) with appropriate thresholding and small-volume corrections for ROIs. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately and are generalizable within the specified age range. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation in healthy adults engaged in social cognition-related processes.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related animacy perception task in healthy adults (n=15 males, mean age 26.6, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (parametric contrasts and t-/F-contrasts) with voxelwise results and tables of MNI coordinates and cluster-level FWE corrections. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a non-empirical paper. Results for the healthy control group are reported explicitly and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of task-evoked whole-brain fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (understanding self and a romantic partner) in healthy adults. Sample: N=42 healthy, right-handed adults aged 23–40 (within 17–65). The task is a task-evoked, ecologically valid social paradigm (video vignettes of partner) contrasting self vs other and valence conditions. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (directional t-contrasts and ANOVA), with family-wise error correction and cluster thresholds; results are presented as tables and figures listing activated regions and corrected statistics. The study does not restrict to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and reports healthy-group task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI with healthy adult controls (n=17) and investigates social reward, it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group. The reported whole-brain table and figures present between-group contrasts (controls > cocaine users) and ROI (SVC) analyses; no standalone healthy-group voxelwise task effect or main effect map is provided. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy-group whole-brain univariate task map. Therefore the paper must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of dynamic vs static facial expressions (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Sample: healthy adult participants (mean ages ~25–26), within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects voxelwise analyses and provides coordinates and cluster results (tables and figures), including contrasts (dynamic>static, task>baseline) generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes whole-brain univariate maps suitable for meta-analysis. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study used resting-state fMRI (seed-to-seed functional connectivity and graph-theory global efficiency) and a behavioral Theory of Mind task (Short Story Task) completed outside the scanner. It did not report any task-evoked, whole-brain univariate fMRI activation maps for a healthy adult group. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring task-based fMRI whole-brain results; it also focuses on resting-state analyses (an explicit exclusion). Participants include adolescents (12–24), so age range partially falls outside 17–65, and no separate healthy adult task-activation maps are provided. Exclude.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social-related face-processing task and includes healthy adult participants (and a healthy-only replication), the primary genome-wide analyses were performed on a combined sample of patients and controls and the paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map clearly identified as coming solely from the healthy/control group. The independent (healthy) replication used an ROI-based analysis (FWE-corrected within fusiform ROI), not an unmasked whole-brain healthy-group map. Therefore it fails the requirement to provide whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked results.

This study reports task-based fMRI of a live, interactive social (joint attention) task that clearly targets social processing. It includes healthy adult participants (two neurotypical groups: an age-/sex-matched control group, n=13, and an independent ROI-control group, n=22; ages in the 18–39 and ~22 ranges), satisfying the sample criterion. The manuscript provides whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts for the healthy/control groups (e.g., RJA>SA, IJA>SA, JA>SA) with tables of coordinates and thresholding details (P<0.001, cluster-corrected) and figures, i.e., unmasked, generalizable healthy-group task activation maps. Results are not reported only as ROIs or connectivity analyses, and healthy-group within-group contrasts are explicitly reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (30 right-handed volunteers screened for psychiatric disorders) using an incidental social task (gender discrimination of emotional faces) assessing perception of others. The paper reports group-level, univariate task-evoked contrasts (fear vs neutral, happy vs neutral, all faces vs baseline) with whole-brain results and coordinates (including supplementary whole-brain comparisons and tables), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Results for the healthy/control sample are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Age range not stated but participants are described as adult volunteers and clearly within 17–65. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

The study should be excluded because it does not match the review’s scope: the task is a non-social visual attention paradigm (not a social-related task), and the participant sample comprises boys/adolescents (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Although whole-brain task-evoked maps are reported, they are not from a healthy adult group performing a social task. Therefore it fails the inclusion criteria for task domain and sample age, and is not eligible for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of action perception/social cognition (mirror system) in healthy adult participants (14 sighted, mean age 32; 8 congenitally blind, mean age 44), both within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses and corrected voxelwise contrasts (e.g., familiar action sounds vs environmental sounds; motor pantomime vs rest), provides statistical maps and cluster-corrected results, and localizes activations in Talairach space. Healthy groups’ results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and includes original task-evoked whole-brain activation maps relevant to perception/understanding of others, satisfying all inclusion criteria.

This paper reports two task-based fMRI experiments probing perception/interpretation of social actions (relevant to social communication/perception of others). Samples: healthy adult participants (Experiment 1 N=20, ages 20–30; Experiment 2 N=20 minus one excluded, ages 19–32), meeting the age criterion (17–65). The manuscript reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain statistical results: searchlight RSA and univariate analyses with corrected cluster maps and tables of peak coordinates (Tables 2 and 3), and univariate baseline contrasts noted in the Supplementary Figures. The analyses are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly described. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, patient-only, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of emotion processing (viewing and rating IAPS emotional pictures), which falls under social-related processing (emotion perception/understanding of self/others). The sample includes healthy adult participants: 25 unrelated healthy controls (mean age 27.5) and 24 unaffected siblings (also psychiatrically healthy), all within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked group analyses (main effect of task across subjects; factorial ANOVA and two-sample t tests comparing groups) with cluster-corrected whole-brain maps and peak coordinates (Table 1 and Figure S2), not limited to ROIs. Results for the healthy/control group are represented within the reported whole-brain maps (and the sample consists of healthy adults), satisfying the requirement for a group-level, generalizable healthy-task activation map. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (mothers aged 22–37) performing a social/affiliative task (viewing own infant vs stranger infant). The paper presents group-level, univariate whole-brain contrasts (own infant > stranger infant) with statistical maps and coordinate tables, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Healthy adult group results are reported separately (N=23 after exclusions). The task probes social/attachment-related processing (affiliation), fitting the review’s constructs. Although ROI and connectivity analyses are also included, these are in addition to clearly reported whole-brain task activation results. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social communication/auditory emotion processing in healthy adults (N=22, ages 19–36), meeting the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., the voice localizer contrast [vocal > non-vocal] yielding TVA clusters, and multiple between-condition contrasts with MNI coordinates and corrected statistics). Although many main effects were examined with ROI-based small-volume corrections, the study nonetheless provides group-level voxelwise activation maps/coordinates derived from the healthy control sample (not limited to a narrowly defined patient subgroup) and reports results that are generalizable to healthy adults. The work is empirical, uses task fMRI (not resting-state or connectivity-only), and therefore satisfies the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social interaction paradigm (multiround trust game) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=21, ages 18–47). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and cluster results for the healthy control group (within-group activations displayed in Figure 2A and thresholded at PFWE<0.05), satisfying the requirement for univariate whole-brain healthy-group maps. Although the sample is female-only, participants are within the 17–65 age range and healthy-group results are reported separately and are generalizable for inclusion in a meta-analysis of social processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n≈25, mean age 26.3) during social-related stimuli (naturalistic film scenes that elicit socio-emotional conflict—perception/understanding of others and social cognition). (2) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (voxelwise contrasts and correlations; Tables/Figures report whole-brain activations, conjunctions, and coordinates for valence prioritization and conflict evaluation). (3) Healthy-control group results are presented separately and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and not ROI-only or resting-state/only connectivity. Therefore it is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of negative social feedback (a social-related task) in healthy adult participants (N=21 males, ages 21–39), fulfilling the sample criterion (healthy adults within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (second-level random-effects contrasts and whole-brain correction; tables and figures present activation foci and coordinates for negative social feedback>positive social feedback under placebo), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The design and results are not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts; healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of emotion perception from body movement (gait), a social-cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Participants: healthy adults (N=19 total; analyses report N=17, ages within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (random-effects GLMs and voxelwise contrasts such as perceived emotional > perceived neutral, parametric GLM for intensity), with corrected multi-subject activation maps projected on Talairach-normalized brains. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain results are explicitly reported and generalizable to the healthy adult group. The study is empirical, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and provides the necessary healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps/contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (eye-gaze perception/inferring others’ attention/intentions). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=18; ages 18–30), satisfying the age and healthy-group requirements. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (second-level GLMs with AQ as a regressor) and lists significant clusters and coordinates (whole-brain FDR-corrected results and tables/coordinates), providing generalizable healthy-group task-evoked effects. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports task-evoked fMRI data in healthy adult participants (n=21 for the imaging experiment) performing repeated retrieval of real-life social interactions (oral examination with an actor), which qualifies as social-related processing (perception/understanding of self/others in a social context). The paper provides group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM8), reporting activations across hippocampus, retrosplenial cortex, medial prefrontal cortex, etc., with corrected statistics (tables and figures referenced), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants were healthy adults within the target age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and includes whole-brain task activation maps; thus no exclusion criteria are triggered. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI during an emotional face perception task (social perception of anger and fear), satisfying the social-related task requirement. Participants are described as healthy adults (no clinical group emphasized) and the paper reports group-level voxelwise task-evoked neural activity in canonical face/emotion regions (amygdala, fusiform, insula). Methods cite whole-brain group analysis procedures (FSL, multilevel linear modeling), indicating univariate whole-brain task effects were tested and reported. Although the paper also reports functional coupling (PPI), this does not preclude inclusion because clear whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group are provided. Minor residual uncertainty remains about explicit age-range reporting in the excerpt, but the sample is consistent with healthy adult participants. Therefore the article meets inclusion criteria.

Although this study uses task-based fMRI with whole-brain voxelwise analyses of a social cognition task (the Eyes task) and reports control-group activations, the sample consists of adolescents aged 12–18 (mean adolescent sample) rather than healthy adults. The inclusion criterion requires at least one group of healthy adult participants (age 17–65) reported separately or as a distinct subgroup generalizable to healthy adults. The paper does not provide a separate adult healthy subgroup or age-restricted analysis for participants ≥17 years that would meet the adult-sample requirement. Therefore it fails the sample-age criterion and must be excluded from the meta-analysis despite meeting other methodological criteria.

While the study includes healthy adult participants (n=27) and a task-based fMRI facial expression discrimination task, the paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. Reported task results are presented as a between-group contrast (patients > controls) showing amygdala hyperactivation in patients; no standalone healthy-group voxelwise task map or coordinates for a healthy-group main effect are provided. The paper’s primary whole-brain results are seed-based resting-state and connectivity analyses and between-group contrasts, which fall under the exclusion criteria. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain univariate task activation map.

The study used task-based fMRI with a social-related paradigm (imaginary sentence completion about ‘My mother’/‘My father’), addressing social/attachment and social communication constructs. It included a healthy adult control group (n=15) and performed voxel-wise one-sample t tests for each group, reporting whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for the healthy controls (e.g., precuneus activation) with cluster FDR correction. Whole-brain between-group contrasts are also reported, but crucially unmasked within-group healthy-control whole-brain results are present. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (task fMRI social processing; healthy adult group; whole-brain univariate healthy-group maps).

Although this fMRI study uses a social cognition task (implicit fearful vs neutral face processing) and includes a healthy control group aged within the target range, the paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. The primary reported results are seed-based PPI effective connectivity and between-group connectivity differences (patients vs controls). The manuscript does not present an unmasked, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (or coordinate table) attributable to the healthy group alone; activations are referenced to a prior publication (Hall et al., 2008). Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task activation and meets the exclusion criterion for reporting only seed-based/effective connectivity without accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task maps.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (nulliparous women aged 19–29) performing social-related tasks (perception of infant cries and faces — social/affiliative and perception/understanding of others). Group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts are reported (e.g., cry vs pink noise; happy vs neutral faces) with whole-brain corrected thresholds and cluster reporting; results are presented as statistical maps, coordinates, and figures. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range, and analyses report healthy-group whole-brain activation effects generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI task involves social-related processing (supraliminal fearful face processing—perception/understanding of others). Includes a healthy adult control group (n=25, ages within 17–65) with results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses for the control group (Supplementary Fig. S1 and Supplementary Table 1 describe whole-brain clusters using FLAME), not only ROI or connectivity results. Not excluded by any listed criteria. Therefore eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social action planning (pantomime gestures), which falls under social communication/perception constructs. It includes a clearly reported healthy adult control group (n=25) matched to patients.
